titleStmt.title: Your fiue gallants As it hath beene often in action at the Black-friers. Written by T. Middleton.
Your five gallants
Your five gallants.
titleStmt.author: Middleton, Thomas, d. 1627.

publicationStmt.publisher: [By George Eld] for Richard Bonlan, dwelling at the signe of the Spred-Eagle, right ouer-against the great north dore of Saint Paules Church,

note.p: Printer's name and publication date from STC.
Reproduction of a photostat of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.p: As it hath beene often in Action at the Black-friers.
Imprinted at London for Richard Boulan, dwelling at the signe of the Spred-Eagle, right ouer-against the great North dore of Saint Paules Church.

div.stage: Presenter or prologue, passing ouer the Stage, the Bawde-gallant, with three wenches gallantly attirde, meetes him the whore-Gallant, the pocket-Gallant, the cheating-Gallant, kisse these three wenches and depart in a little whisper and wanton action: now for the other the Broker-Gallant, bee sits at home yet I warrant you, at this time of day, summing vp his pawnes, hactenus quasi inductio, a little glimpse giuing.

sp.p: IS your pawne good and sound sir?
Ile pawne my life for that sir;
Place your selfe there then, I will seeke to preferre it presently: my Maister is very iealous of the pestilence; marry the pox sits at meate and meale with him.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent the fift day of September to mistresse Onset vpon her gowne, Taffatie petticote with three broad siluer Laces, three pound fifteene shillings.
Lent to Iustice Cropshin vpon both his Veluet Iackets, fiue pound ten shillings.
Lent priuately to my Lady New-cut, vpon her gilt Casting-bottle, and her siluer Lye-pot, fiftie fiue shillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to Sir Oliuer Needy vpon his Taffatie cloake, Beuer hat, and perfumd lether-Ierkin, 6. pound 5. shillings.
May it please your worship—

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Lent to maister Andrew Lucifer, vpon his flame-colourd doublet, and blew Taffity-hose— top the candle sirrah, mee thinkes the light burnes blew when came that suite in.
Tas laine aboue the yeare now?

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Fire and brimstone, cut it out into matches, the white linings will serue for tinder.

And with little helpe sir, they are almost black ynough
allready?— Sir here's an other come with a pawne;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Keepe him aside awhile, and reach me hether the Bill of the last weeke;
Tis at hand sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now sir what's your pawne?
The second part of a Gentlewomans gowne sir, the lower halfe I meane;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I apprehend you easily, the breeches of the gowne!
Very proper, for shee weares the doublet at home, a ghuest that lies in my house sir; she lookes euery houre: for her cousine out at'h country.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh her cousine lies here a may mistake in that? my firend of what parish is your pawne?
Parish why? Saint Clements sir,- Ile come to you presently,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What parish is your pawne my friend. Saint Brides 5. Saint Dunstones none; Saint Clements 3. 3. at Clements, away with your pawne sir, your parish is infected, I will neither purchase the plague for six pence in the pound, and a groat Bill mony, nor venture my smal stocke into contagious parishes: you haue your answer fare-you-well, as fast as you can sir.
The pox arrest you sir at the suite of the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I welcome, welcome.
For I thinke plague scornes your company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I rancke with chiefe Gallants, I loue to smell safely: lent in the vacation to maister Proctor vppon his Spirituall gowne, 5. angels; and vpon his Corporall doublet, 15. shillings. summe 3. pound 5. shillings.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Now sir.

div.stage: Enter his man bringing a trunke.

sp.p: Heer's one come in with a trunke of apparrell.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whence comes it?
From Saint Martins in the field.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Saint Martins in the field,— Saint Mary Maudlin 2. Saint Martins none, her's an Honest fellow, let him appeare sir.
You may come neere sir,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh welcome, welcome what's your pawne sir?
Faith a Gentlewomans whole suite sir.

sp.speaker: Frie.
sp.p: Whole suite? tis well.
A poore kinde soule, troubled with a bad husband; one that puts her to her shifts here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Hee puts her from her shifts me thinkes when she is faine to pawne her clothes?
Looke you sir, a faire Sattin gowne; new Taffaty petticote.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Stay, this petticoate has bene turnd?
Often turnd vp and down & you wil, but neuer turnd sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Cry you mercy indeed:
A fine white Beuer, pearle-band; 3. falls, iha knowne her haue more in her daies.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Alasse and she bee but a Gentlewoman of any count or charge, 3. faules are nothing, in these daies-Know that; tut the worlds chang'd, gentlewomans faules stand vpright now, no sinne but has a Bolster, that it may lye at ease: Well what do you borrow of these sir?
Twelue pound and you will sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?
They were not hers for twenty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why so: our pawne is euer thrice the value of our mony vnles in plate and Iewells, how should the moneths bee restor'd and the vse else? we must cast it for the twelue moneth, so many pounds, so many moneths, so many eighteene pences, then the vse of these eighteene pences, then the want of the returne of those pounds, all these must bee laid togither, which well considered, the valuation of the pawne had need to sound treble: Can six pound pleasure the Gentlewoman.
It may please her, but like a man of threescore in the Limbrest degree.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I haue but one word more to say in't, twenty nobles is all and the vtmost that I will haxard vppon't.
she must be content with't, the lesse borrowed the better paid, come.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Arthur?
At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Tell out twenty nobles, and take her name in a Bill?
Ime satisfied sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Welcome: good Saint Martins in the field, welcome, welcome, I know no other name?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: What so hard at your praiers?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A litle sir, summing vp my pawnes here: what Maister Primero? is it you sir Gallant; and how does all the prety sweete Ladies, those plumpe, kinde, delicate blisses; ha? whom I kisse in my very thoughts: how do they Gallant?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why Gallant? if they should not doe well in my house, where should it be done boy, haue I not a glorious Scituation?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh a Gallant Receit, Violet ayre, curious garden, quaint walkes, fantasticall Arbors, three back-doores and a Coachgate, nay tha'rt admirably seated, little furniture will serue thee, tha'rt neuer without moueables.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I praise my Starres; ah the goodly virginities that haue beene cut vp in my house, and the goodly patrimonies that haue laine like sops in the grauie, and when those sops were eaten, yet the meate was kept whole for another, and another, and another, for as in one pie twenty may dip their sippits, so vpon one woman forty may consume their patrimonies.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Excellent, master Primero?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wel, ile pray for women while I liue, the're the profitablest fooles, ile say that for em, a man can keepe about his house the pretiest kinde fowle, so tame, so gentle e en to strangers, hands, So soone familiar, suffer to be toucht, Of those they nere saw twice: the Doues not like em.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Most certaine, for thats honest; but I haue a suite to you?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And so haue I to you.

lg.l: That happens well,
Grant mine and ile grant yours?

sp.speaker: Pri .
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Make me perfect in that tricke that got you so much at Primero.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh for the thred tied at your partners leg: the twich?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I that twich and you calt so.

lg.l: That secret twich got me fiue hundred pound,
Ere twas first knowne and since I ha sold it well
Fiue hundred pound laide downe shall not yet buy,
The fee simple of my twitch I would be here with't,
Twas a blest inuention, I had bene a beggar many a lowsie yeare
But for my twitch. It was the prettiest twitch?
Many ouer-cheated gulls, haue fatted
Mee with the bottome of their patrimonies
Ee'n to the last Sope, gapte while I fed em;
who now liue by that Art that first vndid e'm.
But I must sweare you to be secret, close,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a maid, at Ten.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Had you sworne but two yeares higher I would here h'a beleeu'd you.

lg.l: Nay I let twelue alone,
For after twelue has struck, mades looke for one.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I looke for one too and a maide I thinke.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What, to come hether?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Sure she followes me? a pretie fat eyde wench, with a Venus in her cheeke, did but Rayment smile vpon her, she were Nectar for great Dons, boy and thats my suite to thee.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And thats granted already: of what volume is this booke, that I may fit a couer too't?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Faith neither in folio, nor in Decimo sexto, but in Octauo betweene both, a prety middle sizde trug.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Then I haue fitted her already: in my eye ifaith: here came a pawne in e'en now will make shift to serue her as fit, looke you sir Gallants, Sattin, Taffety, Beuer, fall and all.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Is it new.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: New? you see it beares her youth as freshly,—

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: A prety suite of cloathes ifaith;— but put case the party should come to redeeme em of a suddaine?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Puh then your wits sickly, haue not I the policy thinke you to seeme extreame busie and defer em til the morrow, against which time that pawne shall bee secretly fetcht home, and another carried out to supply the place.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I like thy craft well there.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: A generall course, oh Frippery is an vnknowne benefit sir Gallant!

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And what must I giue you for the hire now ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Of the whole suite, for the month?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I for the month.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Go to, you shall giue me but twelue pence a day, Maister Primero your a friend, and Ile vse you so, tis got vp at your house in an after-noone ifaith, the hire of the whole month: yea must thinke I can distinguish spirits and put a difference betweene you and others: you pay no more ifaith.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I could haue offred you no lesse, my selfe.

sp.speaker: Fri
sp.p: Tut, a man must vse a friend, as a friend may vse him; your house has beene a sweete house to mee, both for pleasure and profit: ile giue you your due, omne tulit punctum, you haue alwaies kept fine puncks in your house, thats for pleasure, qui miscuit vtile dulci, and I haue had sweete pawnes from em, thats for profit now?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You flatter, you flatter sir Gallant? but whist, here shee enters; I prethe question her? oh y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Is this you new scholler Maister Primero?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Marry is she sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ile commend your iudgement in a wench while I liue, that face will get money ifaith, twill bee a get peny I warrant you? got to? your fortune was choice prety Blisse to fall into the regard of so kinde a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nouice.
sp.p: I hope so sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: See, what his care has prouided already for you, youle be simply set out to the world: if you'l haue that care now to deserue his paines oh that wil be acceptable: and these be the Rudiments you must chiefly point at: to counterfit cunningly, to winde in gentlemen with pourefull attraction, to keepe his house in name and custome, to dissemble with your owne brother, neuer to betray your fellowed imperfections, nor lay open the state of their bodies to strangers, to beleeue those that giue you, to gul those that beleeue you, to laugh at all vnder Taffety, and these be your rudiments.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p:
Ther's e'en al i faith, weele trouble you with no more, nay you shal liue at ease inough: for nimming away iewells and fauours from Gentlemen (which are your chiefe vailes) hope that
wil come naturally inough to you, I need not instruct you, you'l haue that with, I trust to make the most of your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I hope ones mother-wit will serue for that sir.

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: Oh proprest of all wench: it must bee a shee wit that does those things,& thy mother was quick inough at it in her daies.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Giue me leaue sister to examine you vpon 2. or 3. particulers: and you make you ready be no ashamed, hers none but friends— are you a maide.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Yes, in the last quarter sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Very proper, that e'en going out, a maide in the last quarter, thats a whore in the first;— let me see, new moone on Thursday, sheele be chande by that time too; are you willing to pleasure gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: We are all borne to pleasure our country forsooth.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Excellent, can you carry your selfe cunningly, and seeme often holy.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Oh feare not that sir, my friends were all puritanes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ile nere try her furder.

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: She's done well ifaith, I feare not now to turne her loose to any gentleman in Europe.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You need not sir of her owne accord, I thinke she'l bee loose inough without turning— Arthur.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Go make hast, shift her into that suite presently.
It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Arthur do't neately Arthur?
Fear't not sir.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Follow him wench.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: With all my heart sir—.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But maister
In what are we forgetfull al this while?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The wooing businesse man.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Heart thats true.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The Gallants will preuent vs.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Are you certaine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I can auouch it ther's a general meeting,
at the deceasde knights house this afternoone
theres riualship inough.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: No doubt in that?
Would either thou or I might beare her from em.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: My hopes are not yet faint.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Nor mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Tut man?
nothing in womens hearts sooner win place,
than a braue out side and an impudent face?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And for both those weele fit it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I if the deuill bee not int, make halt:

sp.speaker: Fri.

lg.l: I follow straight, vanish thou Fog, and Sinck beneath our brightnesse,
Abashed at the splendar of such beames:
We scorne thee, basse eclipser of our glories,
That wouldst haue hid our shine from nortalls eies,
Now Gallants, I am for you, I and perhaps before you?
You can appearce but glorious from your selues,
And haue your beames but drawne from your owne light,
But mine from many, many make me bright.

sp.p: Heres a dimond that sometimes gracst the finger of a countesse, here sits a Ruby that neere lines blushing for the Party that pawnde it: here a Saphire, O prouidence and fortune! my beginning was so poore, I would faine forget it, and I take the only course, for I scorne to thinke ont. Slaue to a trencher: obseruer of a saltseller, priuy to nothing, but a close-stoole, or such vnsauory secret: but as I striue to forget the dayes of my seruing, so I shall once remember the first step of my raysing, for hauing hardly rakte fiue marke togither, I reioyst so in that small stock, which most prouidently I venturde by water to Blackwall, among fishwiues, and in small time, what by weekely returne, and gainefull restitution it rize to a great body, beside a dish of fish for a present, that stately preserude mee a seauen-night: nor ceast it there but drew on greater profit, for I was held religious by those that do professe like abstinence, and was ful often secretly supplied, by charitable Catholickes, Who censurd me sincerely abstinate, when merely I for hunger nor for zeale, eate vp the fish, & put their almes to vse ha!, ha ha; but those times are runne out, and for my sake, zealous dissemblance has since far'd the worse;— let mee see now, whose cloake shall I weare to day to continue change,
Oh— Arthur.
Here sir.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
Bring downe sir Oliuer Needies Taffetv cloake. & Beuer hat, I am sure he is fast inough? & Andrew Lucifers Rapier and dagger, in the knights ward, with the embost girdle and hangers, for he's in his third sweat by this time, sipping of the doctors bottle, or picking the ninth part of a Rack of mutton drie
roasted, with a leash of night-caps on his head like the popes triple crowne, and as many pillowes crusht to his back, with oh the needles, for he got the pox of a Semster, and it prickt so much more naturally,— quick Arthur quick, now,

lg.l: To the deceast knights daughter
Whome many Gallants sue to, I mongst many: for
Since impudence gaines more respect then vertue,
And come them bloud which few can now deny,
who're your chiefe Gallants, then but such as I.

div.stage: Enter Misters Katherine with Fitsgraue a Gentleman.

lg.l: You do your Beauties iniury, sweete virgin,
To loose the time they must reioyce in youth:
Theres no perfection in a woman placed
But wasts it selfe tho it be neuer wasted,
Then iudge your wrongs your selfe.
Good Maister Fitsgraue?
Through sorrow for the knight my fathers death,
(Whose being was the perfections of my ioye:
And crowne of my desires,) I cannot yet,
But forcedly, on marriage fixe my heart,
Yet heauen forbid I should deiect your hopes
Conceiue not of me so vncharitably,
I should belie my soule if I should say,
You are the man I neuer should affect:
I vnderstand you thus far, you'r a Gentleman
Whom your estate and vertues may command
To a farre worthier brest, then this of mine,
O cease, I dare not heare such blasphemy,
What is without you worthie, I neglect,
In you is placst the worth that I respect:
Vouchsafe vnequalld Virgin whereon I iustly kept,
Accept this worthlesse fauor from your seruants arme, the hallowed beades,
The true and perfect number of my sighs.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Mine cannot equall yours, yet in exchange, accept and weare it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Euen as my Ile rate it?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Heart? Fitsgraue in such bosome single-loues?

div.stage: Enter fiue Gallants at the farther dore.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: So close, and priuate with her?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Obserue hem, he growes proud and bould?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why was not this a generall meeting?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: By her owne consent, Death how I could taste his bloud?

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: See, the gentlemen, at my request do all present them-selues?

lg.l: Manifold blisses waite on her desier,
whose beauty and whose minde so many honour?
I take your wishes thankfully?— kinde gentlemen!
all here assembled, ouer whose long suites,
I neare insulted,
Not like that common sicknes of our sexe,
Grew proud in the aboundance of my suiters,
Or number of the dayes they su'd vnto me.
Dutifull sorrow for my fathers death,
Not willfull coynesse hath my howers detaind
So long in silence:
Im'e left to mine owne choyce, so much the more
My care calls on me If I erre through loue,
Tis I must chide my selfe, I cannot shift
The fault vnto my parents, they're at rest,
And I shall sooner erre through loue, then wealth.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: That likes me well?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Hope still.

lg.l: And my affections do pronounce you all.
Worthy their pure and most intire deserts,
Yet they can choose but one,
Nor doe I diswade any of his hopes,
(Because my heart is not yet throughly fixt,
On marriage, or the man,)
But craue the quiet respite of one moneth,
The moneth vnto this night, against which time,
I doe inuite you all to that election,
Which on my vnstained faith, and Virgin promise,
Shall light amongst no strangers, but your selues:
May this content you?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Glad, and content.

lg.l: 'Tis a good time to leaue,
Till then, commend vs to your gentlest thoughts.

div.stage: They looke scuruily vpon Fitsgraue, and he vpon them. The boy in a corner, with his maister pocket-gallant.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Inough.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Ough.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Hist, maister Hist.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Boye? how now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Looke you sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Her Chaine of Pearle.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I sneckt it away finely.

lg.l: Actiue boy, thy maisters best reuenew, his life & soule
Thou keepst 'em both together? whip, away,
Fall back, fall belly, I must be maintaind,
Hope is no purchase, nor care I if I misse her, why I ranck
In this desiegne with gallants, there's fu'l cause
Policie enuites me to it, 'tis not for loue, or for her sake alone:
It keepes my state suspectlesse and vnknowne.
Their lookes run through, & through me, & the stings
Of their Snake-hissing whispers pierst my hearing:
They're mad she gracd me with one priuate minute,
Aboue their fortunes, I haue obserud em often,
Most spightfully aspected toward my happinesse,
Beyond all others: but the cause I know not,
A quiet moneth the Virgin has enclosde
Vnto her selfe: suiters stand without till then,
In which space cunningly Ile winde my selfe,
Into their Bosomes. I haue be-thought the shape,
Some credulous Scholler, easily infected
With fashion▪ time, and humor. vnto such
Their deepest thoughts, will like to wanton fishes,
Play aboue water, and be all parts seene:
For since at their enuie pines Ile see
Whether their liues from touch of blame sit free.

div.stage: Enter Primero, the Bawde-Gallant, meeting Mistresse New-cut a Marchants wife.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Mistresse New-cut, welcome, here will bee choyse of Gallants for you anon.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is all cleare, may I venture? am I not seene of the wicked?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Strange absurdity, that you should come into my house and aske if you be not seene of the wicked, push, I takt vnkindly ifaith, what thinke you of my house, 'tis no such common receptacle.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Forgiue me sweete maister Primero, I can bee content to haue my pleasure as much as another, but I must haue a care of my credit, I would not bee seene; any thing else; my husbands at Sea, and a woman shall haue an ill report in this world let her carry her selfe neuer so secretly: you know't maister Primero: and what choise of Gallants bee they? will they bee proper Gentlemen thinke you?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Nay sure they are as proper as they will be already.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I must haue choise you know, I come for no gaine, but for sheere pleasure and affection.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You see your old spy-hole yonder, take you stand, please your owne eye, Ile worke it so, the Gallants shall present themselues before you and in the most conspicuous fashion.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That's all I can desire— till better come? looke you.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What meane you Lady?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A trifle sir, to buy you siluer Spurs: good sir accept it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Siluer Spurs, a pritty embleme, marke it, all her gifts are about riding still; the other day shee sent mee Boote-hose wrought in silke and golde, now siluer spurres; well, goe the waies, thou'rt as profitable a spirit as ere lighted into my house; come Ladies come, 'tis late, to Musick, when?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Y'are best command vs: sir, our pimp's growne proud.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: To fooles, and strangers these are Gentlewomen
of sort, and worship: Knights heires, great in portions,
Boorded here for their Musicke,
And often time 'tas beene so cunningly carried,
That I haue had two stolne away at once,
And married at Sauoy and prou'd honest shop-keepers;
And I may safely sweare they practis'd Musicke:
Their naturall at prick-song, a small mist
Will dazle a fooles eye, and thats the world,
So I can thump my hand vpon the table,
With an Austere grace and cry 1 2 and 3,
Fret, stamp and cursse, foh twill passe well for me?
How now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They'r comming in sir,& strangers in their company,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Tune apace Ladies, be ready for the Song sirrah?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Nay I beseech you gallants be more inward with this,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.l: Gentleman his parts deserue it,
Whence come he sir?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Piping hotte from the Vniuersity, hee smells of buttered loaues yet, an excellent scholler, but the arrantest Asse, for this our Soliciter, hee's a rare fellow fiue and fortie myle hence, beleeue that: his friends are of the olde fashion, all in their graues, and now has hee the leysure to follow all fashions, plye the Brothels, Practise salutes and Cringes.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.l: Now deere acquaintance,
Ile bring you to see fashions.

sp.speaker: Firs.
sp.p: What house is this sir?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.l: Oh of great name here musick is profest,
Here some-times Ladies practise, and the meanest,
Daughters to men of worship,
Whom Gentlemen, such as our may visit,
Court, clip and exercise our wits vpon,
It is a profest curtesie.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.l: A prety recreation yfaith.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: I seldome saw so few here, you shall haue'em sometimes in euery corner of the house, with their Violls betwixt their legs, and play the sweetest stroaks twould een filch your soule allmost out of your bosome.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Pax on't: we spoile our selues for want of these things at Vniuersity?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: You haue no such natural happines, let's draw neere,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are all most respectiuely welcome:

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: We are bold and insatiate Suiters sir to the breath of your musicke, & the deere sight of those Ladies.

lg.l: And what our poore skill can inuite you to,
You are kindly welcome: you must pardon 'em Gentlemen,
Virgins and bashfull, besides new beginners,
Tis not a whole moneth since they were first entred.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Seauen yeare in my knowledg▪

lg.l: They blush at their very lessons, they will not indure,
To heare of a Stop, a Pricke, or a Semy-quauer,

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: O out vpon you:

lg.l: La I tell you, youle beare me witnes Gentlemen,
If their complaints come to their parents eares,
Their words of Art, I teach 'em nought but Art.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Why tis most certaine.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: For all Schollers know, that Musica est Ars.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O beastly word?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Looke to the Ladies, Gentlemen;

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Kisse agen?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Come an other?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: this a good Interim?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: what haue you done sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: why? what haue I done,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Saw you their stomacks queasie, and come with such grosse meate!

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why ist not lattin sir,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Lattin? Why then let the next too't be lattin too:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: So ynough?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p:
Nay I can assure you thus farre, I that neuer knew the
language haue heard so much that Ars, is lattin for Art, and it 'may wel be too, for ther's more art int now a daies than euer was:

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: ist possible? I am sorry then I haue follow'd it so farr.

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: A Scholler call you him,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Musicke must not iarre; the offence is satisfied, come to the Song, begin sir.

div.stage: The Song, and hee keepes time, showes seuerall humors and moods: the boy in his pocket nims away Fitsgraues Iewell here, and exit.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Not a whole moneth since you were entred Ladies?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: None that shall see their cunning will beleeue it,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: It is no affliction Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I care not much yfaith, if I write downe to my father presently, to send vp my sister in all haste, that I may place her here at this Musicke schoole.

sp.speaker: Newc.
sp.p: Slid tis the foole my cousin, I would not for the value of three recreations he had seene me here?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How like you your new prize;

sp.speaker: Prip.
sp.p: Pray giue me leaue, I haue not yet sufficiently admir'd her

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: My wits must not stand idle, Slife hee's in a sicke trance?

lg.l: A cheat or two among these mistresses,
Would not be ill bestow'd, I affect none,
But for my pray such are their affections,
I know it, how could drabs and cheaters liue else,
Then since the world rowles on dissimulation,
Ile be the first dissembler.
Prethy loue, comfort, choice, my onely wish in thee
I am confinde, deny me any thing a slight chaine of pearle,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Nay an't be but slight—

lg.l: Being denied,
I prize it slight; but giuen mee by my loue,
Light shall not be so deere vnto my eye;
Mine eye vnto the body as the gift,
How haue I power to deny this to you,
That command all my fortunes are thy seruants,
And thou the Mistresse both of them and me.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: The truest that ere breathd.

lg.l: To a Gentleman,
That thus so long and has so sincerely lou'de you,
As I my selfe, nere was lesse pitty showne.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Why I neuer was held cruell.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: But to me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nor to you.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Go too, 'tas scarde you much,

lg.l: I'me sorry your conceit is so vnkinde,
To thinke me so.
When had I other argument,
I'ue often tendred you my loue and seruice,
And that in no meane fashion:
Yet were you nere that requitefull Mistresse,
That grac'st me with one fauour,
Slight, not so much as such a prety ring, pax on't,
T'as almost broke my heart.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Has tooke it off, Sfoot maister Bouser,

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Nay where a man loues most, there to be scanted.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt,
sp.p: My Ring, come, come.

lg.l: What reckon I a Sattin gowne or two,
If she were wise.

sp.speaker: 2, Curt.
sp.p: Life my Ring sir, come.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Haue you the face yfaith.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Giue me my Ring.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Prethee hence, by this light you get none on't.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: I hold your fauours of more pure esteeme,
Then to part from 'em, faith I doe,
How ere you thinke of me.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Push, pray sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Harke you, go too, you haue lost much by vnkindnesse, goe your wayes.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Sfoot.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But yet there's no time past, you may redeeme it.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come, I cannot misse it ifaith; beside the Gentleman that bestowde it on me, swore to me it cost him twenty nobles.

lg.l: Twenty nobles, pox of twenty nobles,
But you must cost me more, you pritty villaine,
Ah you little roague.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Come come, I know y'are but in iest,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In iest no you shall see.

lg.l: No way will get it.
As good giue it him now, and hope for some-what.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: True loue made iest.

lg.l: I did but trye thy faith, how fast thou'dst hold it,
Now I see a woman may venture worthy fauours to thy trust,
and haue 'em truly kept, and I protest, had I drawn't from thee,
I should nere ha lou'de thee, I know that.
Sfoote I was nere so wrongd in my life,
Thinke you I am in iest with you, what with my loue?
I could finde lighter subiects you shall see,
And time will shew, how much you iniure me.
The Ring wer't thrice worth I freely giue,
For I know you will requite it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will I liue.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Ynough.

lg.l: Why this was well come off now,
Wheres my old Seruingman? not yet returnde,
Oh heere he peepes: now sirrah?

sp.p: May it please your worship— they're done artificially yfaith boy.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Both the great Beakers.
Both Lad.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Iust the same size.
I and the markes as iust.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: So fall off respectiuely now.
My Lord desires your worship of all loue.

lg.l: His Lordship must hold me excusd till morning,
Ile not breake company to night,
Where sup wee Gallants?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: At Mar-maide.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sup there who list, I haue forsworne the house.
Seruing. For the truth is this plot must take effect At Miter.

sp.speaker: Goold.
sp.p: Faith Ime indifferent.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: So are we Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pursu.
sp.p: Name the place maister Goldstone.

lg.l: Why the Miter in my minde,
For neate attendance, diligent boyes and, push, excels it faire.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, the Miter then: Boye, some goodnesse toward, the Boyes whipt away.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: The Iewell, heart the Iewell.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: How now sir? what mou'de you?

lg.l: Nothing sir, a spice of poetrie, a kinde a furie,
A disease runs among Schollers.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Masse it made you stampe.

lg.l: Whoo, till make some stampe and stare, make a strange noyse,
Curse sweare, beate Tire-men, and kick players boyes,
The effects are very fearfull.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Blesse me from't.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Oh you need not feare it sir— hell of this luck.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Harke, hee's at it againe.

lg.l: Some pageant plot, or some deuice for the Tilt-yeard:
Disturbe him not.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: How can I gaine her loue, when I haue lost her fauour.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: What money hast about thee?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Looke you sir, I must be faine to pawne a faire Stone here, for ordinary expences: a pox of my tennants, I giue 'em twenty dayes after the quarter, and they cut out forty.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why you might take the forfeiture of their leases then.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: I know I might, but whats their course? the roagues comes me vp all together, with Geese and Capons, and petitions in pigs shoutes, which would moue any man yfaith, were his stomack nere so great, and to see how pittifully the pullen will looke, it makes me after relent, and turne my anger into a quick fire to roast 'em— nay toucht and spare it not.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Tis right, well, what do's your worship borrow of this sir?

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: The Stone's twenty nobles.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay hardly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: As I am a right Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: It comes neere it indeed: well here's fiue pound in gold vpon't.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Twill serue, and the Ring safe and secret,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: As a Virgins.

lg.l: I wish no hyer: what Gallants▪ are you constant,
Does the place hold?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Miter.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Sir, in regard of our continued boldnesse, & trouble, (which loue to your Musick hath made vs guilty of) shal we intreate your worships company, with these sweete Ladies, your profest Schollers, to take part of a poore Supper with my selfe and these Gentlemen at the Miter.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Pray maister Primere.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: I beseech you sir let it be so.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh pardon me sweet Gentlemen, the worlds apt to censure, I haue the charge of them, they'r left in trust, they'r Virgins, and I dare not hazard their fames, the least touch mars 'em, and what would their right worshipfull parents thinke, if the report should flie to them, that they were seene with Gentlemen in a Tauerne.

lg.l: All this may be preuented, what serues your coach for,
They may come coacht and maskt.
You put me too't sir,
Yet I must say agen, I feare the Drawers,
And Vintners boyes will be familier with them,
And thinke 'em Mistresses.
There are those places where respect seemes slighter,
More censure is belonging to the Miter, you know that sir?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Gentlemen you preuaile.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Weel all expect you there.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And weele not faile.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The diuil wil nere dissemble with them so, as you for them.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What else, lets go,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: How cheere you sir?

lg.l: Faith like the Moone, more bright,
Decreast in body▪ but re-made in light,
Here thou shalt share some of my brightnesse with me.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: By my faith they are comfortable beames sir.

lg.l: Come, where haue you spent the time now from my sight,
Ime iealious of thy action.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Push I did but walke, a turne or two in the garden.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: What made you there?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nothing but cropt a flower.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Some womans honor I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Foh, is this a womans honor.

lg.l: Much about one?
When both are pluckt their sweetnesse is soone gon.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prethe be true to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: When did I faile.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Yet I am euer doubtfull, that your sinne.

lg.l: I do account the world but as my spoile, to adorne thee,
My loue is artificiall to all others,
But purity to thee,— dost thou want gold?
Here take this chaine of pearle, supply thy selfe,
Be thou but constant, firme and iust to mee,
Rich heires shall want, ere want come neere to thee.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Vpon thy lip I seale sincerity.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Was this your vowe to mee?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Pox, whats a kisse to be quite rid of her, shee's sued so long I was ashamde of her, twas but her cheeke I kist neither, to saue her longing.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Tis not a kisse I weigh.

lg.l: Had you weighed this,
T'ad lackt aboue fiue ounces of a true one:
No kisse that ere weighed lighter.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Tis thy loue that I suspect.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: My loue, why by this,— what shall I sweare by?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Sweare by this iewell, keepe thy oth, keepe that.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: By this iewell then, no creature can bee perfect in my loue, but thy deere selfe.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: I rest.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, lets laugh at em sweete soule.

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: I, they may laugh at me, I was a nouice, and beleiude your oths,

lg.l: Why what do you thinke of me, make I no difference,
Turne seauen yeares prostitution, and seauen daies,
Why you're but in the waine of a maide yet:
You wronge my health in thinking I loue them,
Do not I know their populous imperfections.
Why they cannot liue till Easter, let em shew
The fairest side to'th world like hundreds more, whose clothes
E'en stand vpright in siluer, when theire bodie,
Are ready to drop through em, such there be,
They may deceiue the world, they nere shall mee.
Forgiue my doubts, and for some satisfaction were this ring,
From which I vow de nere, but to the, to part.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: With which thou euer bindst me to thy heart.

lg.l: My pocket pickt, this was no brothel-house,
A musick schoole; damnation has fine shapes,
I paide inoug for'th song, I haue lost a iewell
To me more pretious then their soules to them,
That gaue consent to filch it, ile hunt hard:
Wast time and money, trace and wheele about,
But I wil find these secret mischiefes out-how now, whats he:
Oh a seruant to my loue, being thus disguizde,
Ile learne some newes, now sir; you belong to me.

sp.p: I Do sir, but I cannot stay to say, so, nay good sir detaine me not I am going in al hast to enquire or lay waite for a chain of pearle nimd out of her pocket the fift of Nouember, a dismall day.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Ha a chaine of pearle saist thou.
A chaine of pearle sir, which one Maister Fitsgraue a gentleman and a suiter fastned vpon her as a pleadge of his loue.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Ha?

lg.l: Vrge me no more I haue no more to say,
Your friend Ieronimo Bedlam.
Thou'rt a mad fellow indeed, some comfort yet,
Thats hers is missing too, I feele my soule at much more ease: both stolne.
When griefes haue partners they are better borne.
Oh the parting of vs twaine, Enter Whore Gal.
Hath causde me mickle paine, and I shall nere be married,
Vntill I see my muggle againe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Hist?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The nimble gentleman, in the clestiall stockins.

lg.l: Has the best smock fortune, to be belou'd of women?
Valle loo lo lille lo lilo, vallee loo lee lo lillo.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Vallee loo lo lillee lilo, Vallee loo le lo lil'o.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ah sweete gentleman, he keepes it vp stately.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well held ifaith sir— masse and now I remember too, I thinke you nere saw my little banquiting, box aboue, since I alterd it.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why haue you alterd that?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Oh diuinely sir: the pictuers are all new run ouer againe.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: For what had the painter done thinke you, drew mee, Venus naked, which is the grace of a mans Roome you know, & when he had done, drew a number of Oken-leaues before her, had not lawne beene a hundred times softer, made a better shew, and beene more gentlewoman like?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: More ladie-like, a great dea'e.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Come, you shall see how tis alterd now? I do not thinke but you'le like her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Where be your liueries?
They attend without.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Go, call the Coach! Gentlemen, you haue exceld in kindnesse as we in bouldnesse.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: So you thinke amisse sir?

lg.l: Kind Ladies we commit you to sweete dreames,
Our selues vnto the fortune of the dice, dice ho?

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: You rest firme mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: E'en al my soule to thee.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: You keepe your vowes.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why do I breathe, or see?

sp.speaker: Nou.
sp.p: Is your loue constant.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I to none but these now gon, I, now I loue nor them nor thee, slife, I should be cloide, should I loue one in three.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Oh heres maister Bowser now.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Saue you sweete Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Sweete maister Bowser? welcome?

sp.speaker: Pursu.
sp.p: When come these dice.

sp.speaker: Pursu.
sp.p: Yet anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hast thou showne art in em.
You shall be iudge sir, here be the Tauerne Beakers, And here peepe out the fine Alchimy knaues, looking like, wel sir, most of our Gallants, that seeme what they are not.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace villaine, am not I in presence.
Why that puts me in minde of the iest sir.

sp.speaker: Goldst.
sp.p: Agen, you quarter her.
Nay, compare 'em, and spare 'em not.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The bignesse of the bore, iust the same size, The markes, no difference: away, put money in thy pocket, and offer to draw in vpon the least occasion.
I am no babe sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hist.
Whats the matter now?

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Giue me a paire of false Dice, ere you goe.
Pax on't, you're so troublesome too, you cannot remember a thing before, if I stay a little longer, I shall be staid anon.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Here be Dice for your worships.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Oh come, come.

lg.l: The Vintner himselfe,
Ilo shift away these beakers by a slight.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Maister Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now you coniuring raskall?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Blesse your good worship, you're in humors me thinks.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Humors: say that agen.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I said no such wond sir,— would I had my beakers out on's fingers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Whats thy name Vintner?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Iack and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Turne Knight like thy companions, scoundrell, liue vpon vsury, weare thy gilt spurs at thy girdle for feare of slubbering.

lg.l: O no, I hope I shall haue more grace then so sir:
Pray let me helpe your worship.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Cannot I push 'em together without your helpe?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O I beseech your worship, they're the two standards of my house.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Standards, there lie your Standards.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Good your worship; I am glad they are out of his fingers, my wife shall lock 'em vp presently, they shall see no sunne this twelue-months day for this trick.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me come to the sight of your Standards agen.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Your worship shall pardon mee, now you shall not see em in hast I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I do not desire't; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Why maister Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am for you Gallants— Maister Boxeer cry you mercy sir, why supt you from vs?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith sir, I met with a couple of my fellow pupils at Vniuersitie, & so we renew'd our acquaintance & supt together.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fie, thats none of the newest fashion, I must tell you that maister Bouser, you must neuer take acquaintance of any ath' Vniuersity, when you are at London, nor any of London when you're at Vniuersity you must be more forgetfull yfaith, euery place ministers his acquaintance aboundantly.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He tels you true sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I warrant you here's a Gentleman will nere commit such an absurdity.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Who I, no, 'tis well knowne, if I be disposde, Ile forget any man in a seauen-night, and yet looke him in the face: nay let him ride but ten mile from mee, and come home againe, it shall be at my choise whether Ile remember him or no, I haue tryed that.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This is strange sir.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: 'Tis as a man giues his minde too 't sir: and now you bring me in; I remember 'twas once my fortune to be coozned of all my clothes, and with my clothes my money; a poore Shepheard pitting me, tooke me in, and relieude me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done of him ifaith,

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you shall see now, 'twas his fortune likewise not long after, to come to mee in much distresse ifaith, and with weeping eyes, and do you thinke I remembred him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You could not choose.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: By my troth not I, I forgot him quite, and neuer remembred him to this houre.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And yet knew who he was.

lg.l: As well as I know you ifaith—
'Tis a gift giu'n to some aboue others.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: To fooles and knaues they neuer misse on't.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Do's any make such a wonder at this; why alas tis nothing to forget others; what say you to those that forget themselues?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay then to Dice: come set me Gallants, set.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p:
I, fall too 't Gentlemen. I shall heere some newes from some of you anon: I haue th'art to know which loose and nere looke on; Ile bee ready with all the worst money I can finde
about me, Arthur!

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Stand ready.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Feare not me sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: These are mine sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here's a washt Angell, it shall away: Here's Mistresse Rose-noble has lost her maiden-head, crackt in the Ring, shoe's good enough for gaimsters, and to passe from man to man: for gold presents at Dice your harlot, in one houre wone and lost thrice, euery man has a fling at her.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Agen pax of these dice

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Tis ill to curse the dead sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Mew, where should I wish the pox, but among bones.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: He tels you right sir.

lg.l: I nere haue any luck at these odde hands,
None here to make vs fixe— why Maister Frip.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I am very well here I thanke you sir, I had rather be telling my money my selfe, then haue others count it for mee; tis the scuruiest musick in the world me thinkes, to heare my mony gingle in other mens pockets, I neuer had any mind toot ifaith.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Slud play six or play foure, Ile play no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sfoot you see, there's none here to draw in.
Rather then you should be destitute gentlemen, ile play my ten pound, if my maisters worship will giue me leaue.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Come.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: He shall, he shall.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray excuse me Gentlemen: Sfoot how now goodman Rascall, what? because you seru'd my Grand-father when hee went Ambassador, & got some ten pound by'th hand, has that put such spirit in you, to offer to draw in among Gentlemen of worship, knaue.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Pray sir, lets intreate so much for once.

lg.l: 'Tis a vsuall grace ifaith sir,
Yo'ue many gentlemen will play with their men.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I and with their Maides to yfaith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Good sir giue him leaue.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, come, and you be weary on't, I pray draw nere sir.
Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Come foole, feare nothing, I warrant toe, h'as giuen thee leaue, stand here by me, come now, set round Gentlemen, set,

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: How the poore fellow shakes: throw lustily man.
At all gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Well said ifaith.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: The're all mine.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: By my troth I am glad the fellow has such luck, it will encourage him well.
At my maisters worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now sit slaue?
At my maisters worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: So, sawcy raskall.
At my maisters worship alone.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You're a roague and will be euer be one?
By my troth Gentlemen at all agen for once.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Take em to them boy, take em to thee, thou'rt worthy of em ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Gentlemen faith I am angry with you, goe and suborne my knaue againe me here; to make him proud & peremptory.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth thats but your conceite sir, the fellowes an honest fellow and knowes his duty, I dare sweare for him.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Heart, I am sick already.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Whether goes Maister—

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Play on, ile take my turne sir?— boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maister.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Pist?— a supply, cary't closely my little fooker,— how much—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Three pound sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Good boye,— take out another lesson? how now gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Deuills int did you ere see such a hand?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: I set you these three angells.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My maister may set hie?— for all his stakes are drawne out of other mens pockets.
As I said gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Dues Ace.
At all your right worshipfull worships.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Death and vengance!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Hell, darkenesse,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Hold sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Maister Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hinder me not sweete gentlemen— you raskall— I banish thee the boord.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Yfaith but you shall not sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Touch a Die and thou darst, come you in with your lowzie ten pound, you slaue among gentlemen of worshippe, and win thirty at a hand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Why will you kick agen luck sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: As long as the poore fellow ventures the losse of his owne money, who can be offended at his fortunes.
I haue a Maister here? many a Gentleman would bee glad to see his man come forward aha.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Prey be perswaded sir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: 'Slife, here's none cuts my throate in play but he I haue obserude it, an vnluckly slaue tis.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Me thinkes his lucks good inough sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Vpon condition Gentlemen that I may euer bar him from the boord hereafter I am content to winck at him.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Faith, vse your owne pleasure hereafter, has won our mony now! come to'th table sir your master's friends with you.
Pray Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: The fiends int I thinke, I left a faire chaine of pearle at my lodging too, like an asse and nere remembred it; that would ha bin a good pawn now, speake what do you lend vpon these Maister Frip? I care not much if you take my Beuer hat too, for I perceiue tis darke inough already, & it dos but troble me here.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Very well sir why now I can lend you 3. pound sir—

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Prethe do't quickly then?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: There tis in six angels.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Very compendiously.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Here Arthur, runne away with these presently, ile enter em into'th shop-booke to morrow. Item one gilt hatcht rapier and dagger, with a faire imbrodered girdle, and hangers, with which came also a Beuer hat, with a correspondent band.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Push, ifaith sir your to blame, you haue snibd the poore fellow too much, hee can scarce speake, hee cleaues his words with sobbing.
Haff haff, haff, haff at al Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah roague, ile make you know your selfe.
At the fayrest.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Out ifaith— two Aces.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I am glad of that, come pay me al these good-man cloake-bag:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Why are you the fayrest sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: You neede not doubt of that sir— fiue. angells you Scoundrell.
Fie ath these Dice, not one hand to night,— there they go Gentlemen at al ifaith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Pay all with 2. treas and a quater.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Al curses follow em, pay your selues withall, ile pawne my selfe to't, but ile see a hand to night, not once hold in? here Maister Frip, lend me your hand, quick, quick, So.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What do you borrow of this doublet now?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nere saw the world three daies.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Go too, in regard your a continuall customer, ile vse you well, and pleasure you with fiue angels vpon't.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Let me not stand too long ith cold for them:

lg.l: Had euer country gentleman such fortune?
All swoopt away Ide, neede repaire to'th Brokers,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: If you be in that minde sir there sits a Gentleman will furnish you vpon any pawne, as well as the publickst broker of em all:

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Say you so sir, there's comfort in that ifaith.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Item, vpon his oringe tawny sattin doublet, fiue angells,

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: But by your leaue sir? next comes the breeches,—.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh I haue tongue fit for any thing—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Sauing your taile sir? tis giuen me to vnderstand that you are a Gentleman ith hundred, and deale in the premises aforesaide.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Maister Bungler, Maister Bungler, y'are mightily mistooke, I am content to do a gentleman a pleasure for once, so his pawne be neate and sufficient.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why what say you to my Grandfathers seale ring here

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry sir, this is somewhat like.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay view it well, an antient armes, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whats this sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The great codpeice with nothing int.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The word about it, parturiunt montes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Whats that I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: You promise to mount vs.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: And belike he was not so good as his word.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: So it should seeme by the Story, for so our names came to be Bunglers.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A lamentable hearing that so great a house should shrink and fall to ruine.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Two quaters and yet loose it heart, boy?▪ ifaith? what ist?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fiue pound sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: By my troth this boy goes forward well, yee shall see him come to his preferment ith' end!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why how now, whos's that gentlemen, a barge-man?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I neuer haue any luck Gallants, till my doublets off, Ime not halfe nimble inough, at this old finquanter driuelbeard:

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Your worship must pay me al these sir?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: There, and feast the deuill with em.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Hel gnawe these dice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What do you giue ouer Gallants.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: Ist not time.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I protest, I haue but one angell left to guid me home to my lodging.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: How much thinkst?

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Some fourescore angells, sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Peace, weele ioyne powers anon, and see how strong we are in the whole number, masse, yon guilt Goblet stands so full in mine eye, the whorson tempts me, it comes like cheese after a great feast, to disgest the rest, he wil hardly scape mee ifaith I see that by him already; back for a parting blow now,--- boy?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Anon anon sir:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fetch a penneworth of soft wax to seale letters.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I will sir?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay had not I strange casting, thrice togither, 2. quaters and a dews.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Why was not I as often haunted with two treas, and a quater:

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ther's wax for your worship— anon, anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Screene me a little you whorson old crosse biter.

sp.speaker: Fu.
sp.p: Why whats the busines? fil chiton hob Goblet.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: And what has maister Bowser lost?

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Faith not very deepely sir, inough for a scholler, some halfe a score royals.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Sfoot I haue lost as many with spurs at their heeles.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Come Gallants shall we stumble:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Whats a clock.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Heres none ont Dick, the Goblets carried downe.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Nay tis vpon the point of three, boy, Drawer, whats to be done sirs?

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: All's paid, and your worships are welcome, Onely there's a Goblet missing Gentlemen, and cannot bee found about house.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How a Goblet:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: What manner a one▪

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: A guilt Goblet sir, of an indifferent size.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sfoote I saw such a one lately.

sp.speaker: Uint.
sp.p: It cannot be found now sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Came there no strangers here?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This a meruelous matter, that a Goblet should bee gone, and none but wee in the roome, the losse is meere all, heere as we are; keepe the doore Vintner.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: No I beseech your worship.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: By my troth Vintner weele haue a priuy search for this; What? we are not all one womans children.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I beseech yee Gentlemen, haue not that conceit of me, that I suspect your worships.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tut, you are an Asse; do you know euery mans nature: There's a Broker ith' company.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Slife you haue not stole the Goblet, boy, haue you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I was afraide,— tis a good cause ifaith, let each man search his fellow, weele begin with you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I shall saue some body a labour Gentlemen, for Ime halfe searcht already.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thought the Goblet had hung heere ifaith— none heere, nor heere.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Seeke about flower,— What was the Goblet worth Vintne.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Three pound ten shillings sir no more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox on't Gentlemen, tis but Angels a peece, it shall be a brace of mine, rather then I would haue our reputations breathed vpon by all commers, for you must thinke theile talke ont in all companies; such a night, in such a company, such a Goblet, Sfoote it may growe to a gangrene in our credits and bee incurable.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Faith I am content.

sp.speaker: Frip,
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: There's my Angell too.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p:
So, and mine, Ile tell thee what, the missing of this goblet
has dismaide the Gentlemen much.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I am sory for that sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yet they send thee this comfort by me, if they see thee but rest satisfied, and depart away contented, which will appeare in thy countenance; not three times thrice the worth of the Goblet shall hang betweene them and thee, both in their continuall custome, and all their acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I thanke their worships all--- I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Say it againe: do you heare Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: I thanke your worships all I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why la, was not this better then hazarding our reputations vpon trifles, and in such publicke as a Tauerne, such a questionable place.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Faith it was well thought on. Nay keepe your way Gentlemen: I haue sworne maister Bowcer, I will bee last ifaith----- Rascall the goblet.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Where sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peepe yon sir vnder.

sp.speaker: Fulk.
sp.p: Heere sir.

div.head: ACTVS. 4.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: My husband is rode from home, make us delay, I know if your will bee as free as your horse, you will see 'mee yet ere dinner: From Kingston this eleuenth of Nouvember---- Ha? these women are such creatures such importunate sweet soules: theile scarse giue a man leaue to be ready, that's their onely fault ifaith, if they be once set vpon a thing, why there's no remoouing of em, till their pritty wils be fulfild— O pitty thy poore oppressed client here sweete Cupid, that has scarce sixe houres vacation in a moneth, his causes hang in so many Courts, yet neuer suffer my French aduersary, nor his big swolne confederates to ouerthrow me,--- Who without mercy would my bloud carouse, And lay me in prison in a Doctors house:
Thy clemencie great Cupid: peace, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Sir Gallant, well encountred.

sp.speaker: Talb.
sp.p: I both salute, and take my leaue together.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Why whether so fast sir▪

lg.l: Excuse me pray, lme in a little hast,
My horse waites for me.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What some iourney toward?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A light one ifaith sir.

lg.l: I am sorry that my businesse so commands me,
I cannot ride with you; but I make no question,
You haue company inough.
Alasse not any— nor do I desire it,
Why 'tis but to Kingston yonder.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: O cry you mercy sir,

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Scape but one reach, there's little danger thether.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: True a little of Come-parke.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You'ue namde the place sir, that's all I feare ifaith,

lg.l: Farewell sweete maister Taylebee,
This fell out happily; Ile call this purchase mine, before I greete him,
Een where his feare lyes most, there will I meete him: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Walke my horse behinde yon thicket, giue a word, if you discrie.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I haue all perfect sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: So, he cannot now be long: What with my boyes dexterity at Ordinaries, and my Geldings celerity ouer hedge and ditch, but we make pritty shift to rub out, a Gallant, for I haue learnt these principles.

lg.l: Stoope thou toth' world, 'twill on thy bosome tread,
It stoopes to thee, if thou aduance thy head:
The minde beeing farre more excellent then fate,
Tis fit our minde then be aboue our state;
Why should I write my catremitics in my brow,
To make them loath me, that respect me now,
If euery man were in his courses knowne;
Legs that now honor him, might spurne him downe.
To conclude, nothing seemes as it is but honesty, & that makes it so little regarded amongst vs.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Eela, ha, ho.

sp.speaker: Pusn.
sp.p: The Boye: hee's hard at hand, Ile crosse him suddenly: and here he comes; stand.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Deliuer your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I fear'd none but this place ifaith, nay when my minde giues me a thing once.

lg.l: Quick, quick sir, quick.
I must dispatch three robberies yet ere night.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I'me glad you haue such good doings by my troth sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Youle fare neuer a whit the better for your flattery I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I speake sincearly, 'tis pitty such a proper-parted gentleman should want; nor shall you, as long as I haue't about me, nay search and spare not: there's a purse in my left pocket as I take it, with fifteene pound in gold in't, and there's a faire chaine of pearle in the other: nay I'e deale truly with you; it greeues me yfaith when I see such goodly men in distresse, Ile rather want it my selfe then they should go with-out it.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: And that shewes a good nature sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Nay tho I say it, I haue beene alwaies accounted a man of a good nature, I might haue hangd my selfe ere this time els; Pray vse me like a gentleman, take all, but iniury not my body.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: You must pardon me sir, I must a little play the Vsurer, and binde you, for mine owne security.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Alasse ther's no conscience in that sir, shall I enter into bond, and pay money too.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Tut, I must not be betrayd.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Here me but what I say sir, I do protest I would not be he that should betray a man, to be Prince of the world.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Masse that's the diuill, I thanke you heartily, for hee's cal'd prince ath' world.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You take me still at worst.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Sweare on this sword then, to set spurs to your horse, not to looke back, to giue no markes to any passenger.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Markes, why I thinke you haue left me nere a peny sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I meane no markes of any.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I vnderstand you sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Sweare then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ifaith I do sir:

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ime gon sir, by my troth of a fierce theefe he seemes to be a very honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Purs.

lg.l: Why this was well aduentured, trim a Gallant:
Now with a courteous and long thusting eye,

sp.p: Let me behold my purchase, & try the soundues of my bones with laughter, how? is not this the chaine of pearle I gaue to that periurde harlat, tis, Sfoot tis, the very chaine, oh damned mistresse, ha; and this the purse, which not fiue daies before I sent her fild with faire spur-royalls— heart; the very gold?— slife is this no robbery, how many othes flew toward heauen,

lg.l: Which nere came halfe way thether; but like fire drakes,
Mounted a little, gaue a cracke, and fell;
Fainde othes bound vp to sinke more deepe to hell.
What folded papers this? death— tis her hand.

sp.p: Maister Taylbee, you know with what affection I loue you, You do:
I count the world but as my pray to maintaine you, The more dissembling queane you I must tell you,

I haue sent you an embroderd purse here with fifty faire spur-royalls int— A pox on you for your labour wench: And I desire you of all loues to keepe that chaine of pearle from Maister Pursnets sight—
He cannot strumpet, I behold it now, vnto thy secret torture:
So fare thee well, but be constant and want nothing.

As long as I ha't ifayth? me thinkes it should haue gon so,— well; what a horrible age do we liue in, that a man cannot haue a queane to himselfe let him but turne his back the best of her is chipt away like a Court loafe, that when a man comes himself, has nothing but bumbast; & these are 2. simple chippings here, do's my boy pick, & I steale, to enrich my selfe, to keepe her, to maintaine him: why this is right the sequence of the world,— A. L. maintaines her, she maintaines a Knight, he maintaines a Whore, shee maintaines a captaine. So in like manner, the pocket keepes my boye, hee keepes me, I keepe her, shee keepes him, it runs like quick-siluer, from one to another; Sfoote I perceiue I haue beene the chiefe vpholder of this Gallant all this while; it appeares true, we that pay deerest for our pasture are euer likely worse-usde, Sfoot he has a Nag can run for nothing, has his choise, nay and gets by the running of him;— oh fine world strange deuills, and prety damnable affections.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Lela ha, ho?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: There boy, agen, what newes there?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Maister, pist, master?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: How now boye.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I haue discride a prize.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Another lad?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The gull, the scholler?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Maister Bowser:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I, comes along this way:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Without company.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As sure, as he is your owne.

lg.l: Back to thy place boye,
I haue the luck to day, to rob in safety:
Two pretious cowards, whist: I heare him— stand

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You lie, I came forth to goe.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Deliuer your purse.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Tis better in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: How now, at disputations, signior foole.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I'ue so much logick to confute a knaue, a thiefe, a rogue-

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Hold, hold, sir, and you be a gentleman hold, let mee rise.

lg.l: Heart tis the curtizy of his scarf vnmaskt him to me,
Aboue the lip by chance, ile counterfit,
Light, because I am a scholler, you thinke belike that schollers haue no mettal in em, but you shal finde,— I haue not don with you cousin.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: As you're a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: As you're a roague?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Keepe on vpon your way sir:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You bad me stand?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: I haue beene once downe for that:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: And then deliuer?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Deliuer mee from you sir— oh pax on't, has wounded me Eela, ha, ho my horse, my horse boye:

lg.l: Haue you your boy so ready: oh thou world,
How art thou muffled in deceitfull fonnes:
There's such a mist of these, and still hath beene,
The brightnesse of true Gentry is scarce seene:
This iourney was most happily assignde,
I haue found him drosse both in his meanes and minde: what
papers this he dropt? ile looke on't as I goe.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: A gull call you him, let me alwaies set vpon wisemen, theyle be afread of their liues, they haue a feeling of their inniquities, and knowes what tis to die with fighting, sfoote this gull laies on without feare, or wit, how deepe's it sayst thou boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: By my faith three inches sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: La, this was long of you, you roague:

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Of me sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Forgiue me deere boy, my wound akte, and I grewe angry, there's hope of life boy, is there not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Puh, my life for yours.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: A comfortable boye in mans extreames! I was nere so afread in my life but the foole would haue seene my face, hee had mee at such aduantage, hee might haue commanded my Scarfe, I scapt well there tad choakt mee; my reputation had beene past recouery, yet liue I vnsuspected, and stil fit for Gallants choice societies— but here I vowe, if ere I see this Bowser when hee cannot see mee, either in by-lane, priuiledge place, Court, Alley, or come bekinde him when hees standing, or take him when hee reeles from a Tauerne late, pissing againe a Cundit, Wall, or Gate, when hee's in such a plight and cleere from me, ile do that I am ashamde to speake till then.
Nay reade forward, I haue found 3. of your Gallants, like your bewitching shame meerely sophisticall, there's your Bawde-Gallant, your pocket-Gallant, & your Whore-Gallant.
Maister Taylbee.
Thats he
I count the world but as my prey, to maintaine you?
Thats iust the phraze and stil of em all, to him: they meete altogither in one effect, and it may well hold too, for they all iumpe vpon one cause, subands lechery.

lg.l: What shapes can flattery take, let me entreate you,
Both in the virgins right, and our good hopes
Since your houres are so fortunate, to proceede.

sp.p: Why he's base that faires, vntil he crowne his deed.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: See that dissembling deuill, that periurde strumpet.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Welcome my soules best wish,— oh out alasle, thy arme bound in a scarfe, I shall sowne instantly,

lg.l: Heart and ile fetch you agen in the same tune,
O my vnmatched loue, if any sparke of life remaine,
Looke vp, my comfort, my delight, my—

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: O good, o good?

lg.l: The organ of her voice is tunde agen,
Theres hope in women, when their speech returnes:
See like the Moone after a black ecclipse,
She by degrees recouers her pure light:
How cheeres my loue?
As one new wak't out of a deadly trance,
The fit scarce quiet.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Twas terrible for the time, Ide much ado to fetch you.

lg.l: Shrew your fingers,
How came my comfort wounded, speake?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Faith in a fray last night.

lg.l: In a fray? will you loose your bloud so vainely,
Many a poore creature lacks it, tell me how?
What was the quarrell?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Loath to tell you that.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Loath to tell me.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Yet twas my cause of comming.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Why then, must not I know it:

lg.l: Since you vrge it, you shall,
Y'are a strumpet.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: O newes abroad sir?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Say you so.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: Why you knew that the first night you lay with me.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Nay not to me, onely but to the world.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Speake within compasse man.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Faith you know none, you saile without.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: I haue the better skill then.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: At my first step into a Tauerne-roome, to spie that chaine of pearle wound on a strangers arme you begd of me.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: How, you mislooke it sure.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: By heauen the very selfe same chaine.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: O cry you mercy, tis true, ide forgot it, tis S. Georges day to morrow, I lent it to my couzin onely to grace his arme before his mistris.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Notable cunning.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: And is this all now ifaith.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Not, I durst goe further.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Why, let me neuer possesse your loue, if you see not that againe a Thursday morning, I tak't vnkindly yfaith you should fall out with me for such a trifle.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Come, a kisse and friends.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: By this hand Ile spoile your atme and you will not.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: More for this then the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yee, at your booke so hard.

lg.l: Against my will, are you there Signior Logick,
A pox of you sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why how now, what has fate sent vs here, in the name of Venus goddesse of Cypresse.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: A Free-booters pinck sir, three or foure inches deepe.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No more, thats conscionable yfaith.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Troth Ime sory for't, pray how came it sir?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Faith by a paltry fray, in Colman-streete.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Coome-parke he would say.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: No lesse then three at once sir, made a Triangle with their Swords and Daggers, and all opposing me.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: And amongst those three, onely one hurt you sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Ex for ex.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Troth and Ile tell you what luck I had too, since I parted from you last.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What I pray?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The day you offered to ride with mee, I wish now Ide had your company, Sfoote I was set vpon in Coome-parke by three too.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Bah.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Robd by this light of as much gold and Iewels, as I valued at forty pound,

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Sure Saturne is in the fifth house.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I know not that, hee may be in the sixt and he will for me, I am sure they were in my pocket wheresoeuer they were: but Ile nere refuse a Gentlemans company agen when 'tis offered me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I must remember you, 'tis Miter-night Ladies.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Masse 'tis indeed, Friday to day, Ide quite forgot, when a womans busie, how the time runs away.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Oh y'aue betraid vs both.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I vnderstand you not.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Y'aue let him see, the chaine of Pearle I gaue you.

lg.l: Who him: will you beleeue me,
By this hand he neuer saw it.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Vpon a strangers arme he swore to me,

lg.l: Masse that may be, for the truh is ifaith,
I was robd on't 'at Coome-parke.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: Twas that betraid it,

lg.l: I would had staide him,
He was no stranger, he was a theefe yfaith,
For theeues will be no strangers.

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: How shall I excuse it?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay I haue you fast inough boy, you roague.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Good sir, I beseech you sir, let me go.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: A pick-pocket, nay you shall to Newgate luck you: is this your Boy sir.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: How now boy? a monster? thy arme linde fast in an others pocket, where learnt you that manners; what company haue you kept alate, that you are so transformd into a roage, that shape I know not, beleeue me sir I much wonder at the alteration of this boy, where he should get this nature: as good a childe to see to, and as vertuous, hee has his Creed by heart, reads me his chapter duly euery night; hee will not misse you one tittle in the nine commandements.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: Theres ten of em.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I feare he skips ore one; thou shalt not steale.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Masse like enough.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Else grace and memory, would quite abash the boy. Thou gracelesse impe, ah thou prodigious child, begot at some ec ipse, degenerate rogue. Shame to thy friends, and to thy maister eke: how far digressing from the noble minde of thy braue Ancesters that lie in Marble, with their coate armors ore em.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Had he such friends?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: The boy is well discended, though he be a rogue and has no feeling ont, yet for my sake, & for my reputations seeke not the bloud of the boy, his neere allyed to many men of worship now yet liuing, a fine old man to his father, it would kill his heart yfaith, heed away like a Crysom.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Alasse good gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Ah shameles villaine, complainst thou? dost thou want?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Art not well clad, thy hunger well resisted.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, yes,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: But thou shalt straight to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sweet maister.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Liue vpon bread and water, and chap choake.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I beseech your worship.
