sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Come Ile be his suerty for once:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: You shall excuse me indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: He will mend, a may proue an honest man for all this, I know gallant Gentlemen now, that haue done as much as this comes too in their youth.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Say you so sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: And as for Bridewell, that will but make him worse, a will learne more knauery there in one weeke, then will furnish him and his heires for a hundreth yeare.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Deliuer the boy.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay I tell you true Sir, ther's none goes in there a queane, but she comes out an arrant whore I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: The boy comes not there for a million.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: No you had better forgiue him by ten parts.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: True, but a must not know it comes from me, downe a your knees you rogue, and thanke this gentleman has got your pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O I thanke your worship:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: A pox on you for a rogue, you put me to my sette speech once a quarter:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay gentlemen you quite forget your houre, lead maister Bowser
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Gold; and Curtisan.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Let me go you'r a dissembler

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Did not you promise me a new gowne?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I not? yes faith did I, and thou shalt haue it, goe sirrah runne for a Tayler presently.
Let me see for the coulour now; Orange tawny, Peach colour, what sayst to a Watchet Sattin?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: O tis the onely colour I affect.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: A very orient colour, ant please your worships, I made a gowne ont for a Gentlewoman tother day, and it does passing well vpon her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A Watchet Sattin gowne.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: There your worship left sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Laid about Tayler.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: Very good Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With foure faire Laces.

sp.speaker: Tayler.
sp.p: That will be costly sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How you rogue costly, out ath'house, you slip-shood, shamlegd, browne-thred, penny-skeand rascall.

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: Nay my sweete loue.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hang him rogue, he's but a Botcher neither, come Ile send thee a fellow worth a hundred of this, if the slaue were cleane inough.

div.stage: In the midst of the musick enter one bringing in a suite of Satin, knocks at Taylbees doore, enter his man.

sp.p: Who knocks.
A Christian: pray is not this maister Taylbees lodging, I was directed hether.
Yes, this is my maisters lodging.
Cry you mercy sir. Is he yet stirring.
Hee's awake, but not yet stirring, for he plaide away halfe his clothes last night
My mistresse commends her secrets vnto him, and presents him by me with a new Sattin suite here.
Masse that comes happily.
And she hopes the fashion will content him.
Ther's no doubt to be had of that sir— your mistresse name I pray? y'are much pretiously welcome.
I thanke you vncommonly sir.
The suite shall be accepted I warrant you sir.
Thats all my Mistresse desires sir.
Fare you well sir.
Fare you well sir.
This will make my maister leape out of the bed for ioy, and dance Wigmois galliard in his shift about the chamber?

div.stage: The Musicke plaies on a while, then enter; Taylbee his man after trussing him.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Came this suit from mistris Cleeueland?

sp.speaker: Iacke.
sp.p: She sent it secretly sir.

sp.speaker: Taylb
sp.p: A pritty requitefull squall, I like that woman, that can remember a good turne 3 moneths a'er the date, it shewes both a good memory, and a very feeling spirit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: This came fortunately sir, after all your ill lucke last night.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I'de beastly casting Iacke.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Oh abominable sir, you had the scuruiest hand— the old Seruingman swoopt vp all;

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: I am glad the fortune lighted vpon the poore fellow by my troth, tmade his maister mad?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Did you marke that sir, I warrant hee has the doggedst maister of any poore fellow vnder the dog-signe, Ide rather serue your worship, Ile say that behinde your backe sir, for nothing, as indeed I haue no standing wages at all, your worship knowes.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Oh but your vailes Iacke your vailes considered, when you run too and fro betweene me and mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ia
sp.p: I must confesse my vailes are able to keepe an honest man go I where I lift.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: go to then Iacke.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: But those vailes stand with the state of your body sir as long as you hold vp your head, if that droop once, farewell you, farewell I, farewell all, and droop it will, though all the caudles in Europe should put to their helping hands toot; tis ee'n as vncertaine as playing now vu now downe, for if the Bill rise to aboue thirty, heer's no place for players, so if your yeares rise to aboue forty, ther's no roome for old lechers.

sp.speaker: Tabl.
sp.p: and thats the reason all roomes are taken vp for young Temp'ers?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: y'are in the right sir?

sp.speaker: Talb.
sp.p: pize ont I pawnd a good beuer hat to maister Frip last night Iacke,
I feele the want of it now,— harke whos's that knockes;
Is maister Taylbee stirring?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Whats your pleasure with him, he walks here ith hall.
Giue your worship good morrow,

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Welcome honest lad;
A letter from my mistresse.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Whos's the mistresse?
Mistresse new blocke.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Mistress new-blocke my sincere loue how do's she?
Faith onely ill the want of your sight.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Alasse deere sweet, Iu'e had such buisines, I protest I nere stood still since I saw her.
She has sent your worship a Beuer hat heere, with a band best in fashion.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: How shall I requite this deere soule?
Tit not a thing fit for mee to tell you sir, for I haue three yeares to serue yet: your worship knowes how I warrant you;

sp.speaker: Talb.
sp.p: I know the drift of her letter, and for the Beuer, say, I accept it highly.
Oh shee will be a proud woman of that sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And harke thee tell thy mistresse as lm'e a Gentleman, Ile dispatch her out of hand, the first thing I do a my credit, canst thou remember these words now?
Yes siras you are a Gentleman you'le dispatch her out of hand the first thing you do

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ia my credit.
Oh of your credit, I thought not of that fir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Remember that good boy?
Feare it not now fir.

sp.speaker: Tayl
sp.p: I dreamt to nighe Iacke, I should haue a secret supply out a'th Citty

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Your dreame craules out partly well sir,— what newes there now?
I haue an arrant no maister Taylbee—

sp.speaker: Iacke.
sp.p: Yonder walks my maister;

Mistres Tiffany commends her to your worship and h'as sent you your ten pound in gold backe gaine, and sayes shee cannot furnish you of the same Lawne you desire, till after
all hollantide—

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Thanke her she would let me vnderstand so much? ha, ha,— this wench wil liue, why this was sent like a worke woman now, the rest are borchers to her, faith I commend her cunning, shees a foole, that makes her seruant fellowe to her heart, it robs her of respect, dams vp all duty, keepes her in awe e'en of the slaue shee keepes.

lg.l: This takes a wise course I commend her more,
Sends back the gold, I neuer sawe before:
Well women are my best friends ifaith,
Takes lands giue me good legs:
Firme back white hand black eye, browne haire,
And ad but to these fiue a comly stature,
Let others liue by art and I by nature.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Maister Bowser Maistr Bowser, ha, ha, ho, maister Bowser.

sp.speaker: Fusg
sp.p: Holla:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What not out of thy kennel, Maister Bowser.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Maister Goldstone, your an early Gallant sir?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: A faire cloake yonder ifaith,— by my troth a bed Maister Bowser, you remember your promise well ore night.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Why whats a clock sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Do you aske that now, why the chimes are spent at Saint Brides.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Tis a Gentlemans houre, saith Maister Goldstone ile bee ready in a trice.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away theres no trust to you:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Faith ile come instantly?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay chuse whether you will or no, by my troth your cloake shall goe before you—

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Nay Maister Goldstore I ha sworke— do you heare sir:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Away, away, faith Ime angry with you, pox, a bed now Ime ashamde of it.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p:
Foote my cloake, my cloake Maister Goldstone, slife what meant you by this sir you'le bring it back agen, I hope, no not yet, by my troth I care very little for such kinde of iesting, me thinkes this familiarity now extends a little too far, vnlesse it be a new fashion come forth this morning, secreetly yesterday twould haue showne vnmannerly, and sawcily; I scarce
know yet what to thinke on't, well there's no great profit in standing in my shirt, ile on with my cloathes, has bound mee to follow the suite, my cloakes a stranger hee was made but yesterday, & I do not loue to trust him alone in company.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: What may I coniecture of this Goldstone? hee has not onely pawnde to me this cloake, but the verie Diamond and Saphire, which I bestowde vpon my new loue at Maister Primeroes house; the cloakes new and comes fitly, to do me great grace at a wedding this morning, to which I was solemnly enuited. I can continue change more than the proudest Gallant of em all; yet neuer bestowe pennie of my selfe, my pawnes do so kindly furnish mee: but the sight of these iewells is able to cloy me, did I not preserue my stomack the better for the wedding dinner, a guift could neuer haue come in a more patient houre, nor to be better disgested; is she prou'd false,— but Ile not fiet to day nor chafe my bloud.

sp.speaker: Pursu.
sp.p: Ha, yonder goes Bowser, the place is fit:— boy stand with my horse at Corner, I owe you for a Pinck 3. inches deepe sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On— o— o;

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Take that in part of payment; for Coome-parke:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: On— o— o?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: How now, whos's this? sfoote one of our Gallants, knockt downe like a Calfe, is there such a plauge of em here at London, they begun to knock em ath head already:

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh Maister Bowser, pray rend me your hand sir; I am slaine:

lg.l: Slaine and aliue? oh cruell execution?
What man so sauage-spirited durst presume,
To strike downe sattin on two taffeties cut:
Or lift his hand against a Beuer hat.
Some toague that owes me money, and had no other meanes
To a wedding dinner: I must be d'est myself me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Fit'g.
sp.p: How why this my cloake, life how came my cloake hether?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Is it yours sir,? Maister Goldstone pawnde it to me this morning fresh and failing▪ and borrowed fiue pound vpon't.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: How, pawnde it? pray let me neare out this story, come, and ile lend you to the next barbers-surgeons;— pawnde my cloake?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: How now Marmaduke what's the wager;

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Nay my care is at end sir, now I am come to the sight of you? my mistris your couzin entreates you to take part of a dinner with her at home at her house, and bring what Gentleman you please to accompany you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Thanke my sweet couze, ile munch with her say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ile tell her so.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Marmaduke—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Will there be any stock-fish thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Tell my couze I'ue a great appetite to stock-fish ifaith— Maister Goldstone ile intreate you to bee the gentleman that shall accompany me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Not? me sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: You sir.

sp.speaker: Bung
sp.p: By my troth concluded, what state beares thy couze sirrah?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Oh a fine Merchants wife,—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Or rather a Merchants fine wife—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Trust me and thats the properer phraze here at London, and tis as absurd too, to call him fine Merchant, for being at sea, a man knowes not what pickle he is in.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Why true—

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Yet my couze will be serude in plate I can tell you, she has her siluer Iugs and her guilt Tankards.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Fie.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Nay you shall see a house drest vp ifaith, you must not thinke to tread ath ground when you come there.—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: No, how there?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why vpon paths made of fig-frailes, & white blankets cut out in steakes.

sp.speaker: Go
sp.p: Away— I haue thought of a deuice, where shal we meete an houre hence.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: In Powles.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Agreed.

lg.l: The Broker-Gallant, and the Cheating-Gallant,
Now I haue found 'em all, I so reioyce,
That the redeeming of my cloake I wey not:
I haue spyed him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pax here's Boucer.

sp.speaker: Fits
sp.p: Maister Goldstone, my cloake, come wher's my cloake sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh y'are a sure Gentleman; especially if a man stand in need of you, he may bee slaine in a morning to breakfast, ere you vouchsafe to peepe out of your lodging.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No lesse then foure Gallants, as Ime a gentleman, drew all vpon me at once, and opposde mee so spightfully, that I not onely lost your cloake ith' fray.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Comes it in there?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But my riche Hangers, sirrah, I thinke thou hast seene em.

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Neuer ifaith sir.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Those with the two Vnicornes, all wrought in Pearle and gold pex on't it frets me ten times more then the losse of the platty cloake; prethee and thou lou'st me speake no more on t, it brings the Vnicornes into my minde, and thou wouldst not thinke how the conceit greeues me: I will not do thee that disgrace ifaith, to offer thee any satisfaction, for in my soule I thinke thou scornst it thou bearst that minde in my conscience▪ I haue alwaies said so of thee; fare thee well, when shall I see thee at my chamber, when?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: Euery day shortly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I haue fine toyes to show thee.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You win my heart then:

The Diuill scarce knew what a portion hee gaue his children, when he allowde 'em large impudence to liue vpon, & so turnd em into th'world, surely he gaue away the third part of the riches of his kingdome, reuenues are but fooles too't; the filed tongue and the vndaunted fore-head,

lg.l: Are mighty patrimonies, wealthier then those
The Citty-Sire, or the Court-father leaues,
In these behold it, riches oft like slaues
Reuolt, they beare their fore-heads to their graues,
What soonest grasps aduancement, me & great suites
Trips downe rich widowes, gaines repute and name,
Makes way where ere it comes, bewitches all
Thou impudence, the minion of our dayes
On whose pale cheekes fauor and fortune playes!
Call you these your fiue Gallants, trust me they'r rare fellowes
They liue on nothing; many cannot liue on something,
Heere they may take example;— Suspectlesse virgin!
How easie had thy Goodnesse bene beguilde
Now onely rests, that as to me they'r knowne,
So to the world their base Arts may be showne.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Art sure thou saw'st him receiu't boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Forty pound in gold as Im'e a gentleman borne,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Thy father gaue the Rams-head boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No you'r deceiu'd my mother gaue that sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: whats thy mothers, is thy fathers;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Im'e sorry it holds in the Rams-head, see heere he walkes, I was sure hee came into Powles, the gold had bene yours maister long ere this, but that he weares both his hands in his pockets:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: How vnfortunately is my purpose seated, what the deuill should come in his minde to keepe in his hands so long, the biting but of a paultry louse would do me great kindnes now, I knew not how to requite it, will no rascall creature assist mee, stay, what if I did impudently salute 'em out, good, boy be redy boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: vpon the least aduantage sir?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: You'r most deuoutly met in Powles sir?

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: So are you, but I scarce remember you sir.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Oh I cry you mercy sir, I pray pardon me I feare I haue tendred an offence sir, troth I tooke you at the first for one maister Dumplin a Norfolke gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: Ther's no harme done yet sir?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: I hope hee is there by this time, how now boy, hast it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No by troth haue I not, this labours lost, 'tis in the right pocket, and he kept that hand in sure enough.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Vnpractizd Gallant, salute me but with one hand, like a counterfeit souldier, O times and manners? are wee growne beasts, doe wee salute by halfes, are not our limbes at leisure, wheres comely nurture, the Italian kisse, or the French cringe, with the Polonian waste: are all forgot, then misery followes— Surely fate forbad it, had hee imploide but his right hand, Ide had it:— It must be an euerlasting deuise I thinke, that procures both his hands out at once: do you walke sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: No I stay a little for a Gentlemans comming too.

sp.speaker: Piam.
sp.p: Farewell then sir, I haue forty pound in gold about me, which I must presently send downe into the countrey.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Fare you well sir: I wonder Maister Goldstone spares my company so long, 'tis now about the nauill of the day, vpon the belly of noone.

div.stage: Enter Goldst. and his man disguisde both.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: See where he walkes, be sure you let off at a twinckling now.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.p: When did I misse you,— your worship has forgot, you promist Mistresse Newcut your cozen, to dine with her this day.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Masse that was well remembred.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am bold to salute you sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Is Mistresse New-cut your coozen sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, shee's a coozen of mine sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Then I am a coozen of yours, by the Sisters side.

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Let me salute you then, I shall be glad of your farther acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I am a bidden guest here too.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Faith inuited this morning.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Your good company, shall be kindly imbrac'd sir.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I walke a turne or two here for a Gentleman, but I thinke heele either ouer-take me, or be before me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Tis very likely sir; there sirrah, go to dinner, & about two waite for mee?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Nay let him come betweene two and three coozen, for we loue to sit long at dinner ith' Citty.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come sweete coozen.

lg.l: Nay coozen, keepe your way coozen,
Good coozen I will not yfaith coozen.

sp.speaker: New,
sp.p: Why how now sirtah, vpon twelue of the clock, & not the cloth laide yet— must we needs keepe Exchange time still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am about it forsooth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are about it forsooth; y'are still about many things, but you nere do one well, I am an Asse to keep thee inth 'house now my husbands at sea, thou hast no audacity with thee, a foolish dreaming lad, fitter to be in the garret, then in any place else, no grace, nor manly behauiour; when didst thou euer come to mee, but with thy head hanging downe, oh decheerefull prentize, vncomfortable seruant: pray heauen the Gull my coozen has so much wit left, as to bring maister Taylbee along with him; my comfort, my delight, for that was the chiefest cause I did inuite him, I bad him bring what Gentlemen he pleazd to accompany him, as farre as I durst goe, why may hee not then make choise of maister Taylbee, had hee my wit or feeling hee would doo't.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Wher's my sweet coozen here, dos she lack any guesse?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Euer such guesse as you, y'are welcome coozen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am rude Lady.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are most welcome sir.

lg.l: There will be a gallant here anon cooze,
Hee promist faithfully.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Who ist maister Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Maister Taylbee, no maister Goldstone.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Maist. Goldstone; I could thinke well of that Goldstone, wert not for one vilde trick he has.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Whats that Lady?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: In iest, he will pawne his punc es for suppers.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Thats a vilde part in him ifaith, & he were my brother.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Pray gentlemen sit a while, your dinner shall come presently.

lg.l: Yee mistresse New-cut, at first giue me a trip,
A close bite alwayes askes a secret nip.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: My coozen here is a very kind natur'd soule ifaith, in her humor.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Puh you know her not so wel as I cooze, I haue obseru'd her in all her humors you nere saw her a little waspish I thinke.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: I haue Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Puh, then yea nere sawe prety humor in your life, I can bring her into't when I list.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Would you could ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Would I could? by my troth and I were sure thou couldst keepe thy countenance couze, what a prety iest haue I thought vpon already to entertaine time before dinner.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Preche couze what ist, I loue a iest a life ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Ah but I am iealious you will not keepe your countenance ifaith.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why yea shall see a prety story of a humor.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Faith ile try you for once, you know my couzin will wonder when she comes in to see the cloath layd and nere a salt vpon the boord.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Thats true ifaith.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Now will I stand a while out of sight with it, and giue her humour play a little.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Couze dost thou loue mee, and thou wilt euer doe any thing for me, do't.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Marry I build vpon you countenance.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why dost thou thinke Ime an asse couze?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: I would be loath to vndertake it else, for if you should burst out presently, couze the iest would be spoild.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Why do not I know that, away, stand close, so, so mum couzen? a merry companion ifaith, here will be good sport anon,— whist she comes?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I make you stray long for a bad dinner, here couzen, if Maister Goldstone were come, the meates e'en ready.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: Some great busines detaines him couzin, but heele not be long now?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why how now, cuds my life,—

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Was euer mistris so plaugd with a shetle-headed seruant— why Marmaduke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I come forsooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Able to shame me from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Did you call forsooth?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come hether forsooth— did you lay this cloth?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes forsooth:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you vse to lay a cloth without a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt, a salt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many salts would you haue, Ime sure I set the best ith house vpon the boore.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: How? couzen:— sings— couzen, couzen, did call couze.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Did you see a salt vpon the boord when you came in.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: Puh.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Come, come, I thought as much, beshrew your singers, where ist now?

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Your couzen yonder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why the mans mad.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Couzen, hist couzen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What say you.

sp.speaker: Bun.
sp.p: Puh, I call not you, I call my couzen, come forth with th' salt couzen: ha, how, nobody: why was not he that came in e'en now your couzen?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My couzen: O my bell salt, O my great bell salt.

sp.speaker: Bung.
sp.p: The tenor bell salt; oh here comes Maister Goldstone now couzen, he may tell vs some newes on him. Did you not meete a fellow about doore, with a great siluer salt vnder his arme.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No sure, I met none such.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I forgot all this while to bid you welcome. I shall loth this roome for euer. Take hence the cloth you vnlucky maple-fac'd rascall, come you shall dine in my chamber sir.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: No better place lady.

sp.speaker: Pya.
sp.p: No lesse then forty pound in faire gold at one lift, the next shall sowne, and sowne agen till the diuill fetch him ere I set hand to him, heart, nothing vexes mee so much▪ but that I payde the Goldsmith for the change too not an houre before, had I let it alone in the chaine of siluer as it was at first, it might haue giuen mee some notice at his departure, sfoote I could fight with a win-mill now, sure twas some vnlucky villaine, why should he come and salute mee wrongfully too mistake me at noone day, now I thinke ont in cold bloud? it could not be but an induction to some villanous purpose, well, I shal meete him—

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: This forty pound came fortunately to redeeme my chaine of pearle from morgage, I would not care how often I sowned to haue such a good cawdle to comfort me, gold and pearle is very restoratiue.—

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: See yonders the roague I suspect for fowle play, ile walke muffled by him, offer some offence or cause of a quarrel, only to try his temper, if he be a coward, he's the likelier to be a roague, an infallible note.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What a pox aile you sir, would I had beene aware of you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Sir, speake you to me?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Not I sir, pray keepe on your way I haue nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Y'are a raskall.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: You may, say your pleasure sir,— but I hope I goe not like a raskall.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you▪ faine to flie to your cloathes, because y are Gallant, why theres no raskall, like your Gallant raskall beleeue that.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: You haue tooke mee at such an houre, faith you may call me e'en what you please, nothing wil mooue me.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: No, ile make somewhat mooue you? drawe? I suspected you were a roague, & you haue purst it vp wel with a coward?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Who my Patron.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Keepe out you raskall.

lg.l: The gest that did me the kindnesse in Powles,
Hold as you are a gentleman, youle giue me breath sir.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: Are you there with mee, a vengeance stop you, you haue found breath inough to run away from mee I will neuer meete this slaue hereafter in a morning but I will breath my selfe vpon him, since I can haue no other satisfaction, hee shail saue me that forty pound in fence-schoole.

sp.speaker: Gold.

lg.l: When things are clenly carried, signe of iudgement,
I was the welcomst Gallant to her aliue,
After the salt was stolne; then a good dinner,
A fine prouoking meale which drewe on apace,
The pleasure of a day-bed, and I had it:
This here one ring can witnesse, when I parted,
Who but seewte Maister Goldstone, I left her in that trance.
What cannot wit so it be impudent
Deuise and compasse? I would faine know that fellow now,
That would suspect me but for what I am.

sp.p: He liues not,; 'Tis all in the conueyance, what? Thou lookst not like a begger, what makst thou on the ground, I haue a hand to help thee vp, a faire chaine of pearle, surely a marchants wife giues lucky bandsell; they that finde pearle may wear't at a cheape rate, mary my Lady dropt it from her arme for a deuice to toale me to her bed, Iu'e seene as great a matter— who be these? Ile be to crafty for you, oh mounsier Primero, Signior Frip, is it you gallants.

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Sweet maister Goldstone?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: euery bawd exceeds mee in fortune: maister Primero was rob'd of a Carkanet vpon monday last▪ laid the goldsmiths and found it. I h'a laid goldsmits Ieweller, Burnisher Broker, and the deuill and all I thinke, yet could neuer so much as here of that chaine of pearle, he was a notable theefe, hee workes close; peace, who be these, ha mee see, by this light there it 'tis backe least they see thee; a happy minute, Goldstone what an age do we breath in, who, that saw him now would thinke hee were maintaind by purses: so, who, that meets me, would thinke I were maintaind by wenches, as far as I can see tis all one case, and holds both in one Court, wee are both maintaind by the common roade way? Keep thou thine owne heart, thou liu'st vnsuspected, I leese you againe now.

lg.l: But I pray you tell me,
met you no Gentlewomen by the way you came?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Not any what should they be?

lg.l: Nay I do but aske,
Because a Gentlewomans gloue was found,
Neere to the place I met you?

sp.speaker: Primero.
sp.p: Faith we saw none sir.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: good officers, vpon suspition of fellony.

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Very good sir
What call you the theefs name you do suspect?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Maister Iustinian Goldstone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Remember, maister Iustice Goldstone, a terrible world the whilst, my Maisters.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Looke you that's he; vpon him officers.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: I see him not yet, which is he sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why that.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He a theefe sir, who that Gentleman ith' Satt in?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Een hee.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Farewell sir, y'are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: As you will answer it officers, Ile beare you out, Ile be your warrant.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Nay and you say so, what's his name then.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Iustinian Goldstone.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Maister Iustinian Goldstone, wee apprehend you sir vpon suspition of fellonie.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mee.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: You sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I charge you in the Kings name gentlemen to assist vs.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Maister Taylbee?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The same man sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Life whats the newes?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha you forgot Come-parke?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come-parke? no, tis in Kingstone way.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: I beleeue youle finde it so.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I not deny it.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Beare witnesse has confest.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: What haue I confest, paire of cockscombes indubitable?

lg.l: I was robd finely of this chaine of Pearle there,
And forty faire Spur-Royals.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did I rob you?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: There where I finde my goods I may suspect sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I dreamt this would be his end.

lg.l: See how I am wrongd Gentlemen:
As I haue a soule, I found this chaine of pearle,
Not three yeards from this place, iust when I met you.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yet the law's such, if he but sweare 'tis you, y'are gon.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pox ont, that ere I saw't.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Can you but sweare 'tis he, do but that, and you tickle him yfaith?

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Nay and it come once to swearing let me alone:

sp.speaker: Frip
sp.p: Say and hold, hee call'd my Iewells counterfet, and so cheated the poore wench of 'em:

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Come bring him away, come?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Twill call my state in question!

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I thinke what's got by theft doth neuer prosper, Now lost my chaine of pearle— come maister Goldstone, lets go this mine yfaith,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The chaine of pearle?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: By my trothit's mine;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: By my troth much good do't you sir?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Im'e glad in my soule fie— Gnawes,

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Deliuer your weapons,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: You're apprehended vpon supition of fellony?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Fellony? what's that'

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: Was it you yfaith, sir all this while, that did me that kindnes to ease both my pockets at Coom-parke:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: I sir? pray gentlemen draw neere, lets talke among our selues, stand a part Scoundrell;— must euery gentleman be vp braided in publike that flies out now and then vpon necessity, to be Theames for pedlers and weauers? this should not bee, twas neuer seene among the Romaines; nor read we of it in the time of Brute▪ are wee more Brutish now? did I list to blab, do not I know your course of lise maister Taylbee to bee as base as the basest, maintaind by mee, by him by all of vs, and a second hand from mistresses, Iu'e their letters heere to show?
Why should you be so violent to strip naked

Anothers Reputation, to the world knowing your owne so leprous, Beside this chaine of pearle and those spur-royals came to you falsely for she broke her faith, and made her soule a strumpet with her body, when she sent those; they were euer iustly mine? Pray what moues you sir, why should you shake your head, you'r cleere, sure I should know you sir, pray are not you sometimes a pandar, & oftner a bawd sir, haue I neuer Sin'd in your ban-quetting boxes, your bowers and towers? you slaue, that keeps fornication vpon the tops of trees, the very Birds cannot in gender in quiet for you, why rogue, that goes in good clothes made out of wenches cast gownes.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Nothing goes so neere my heart as that?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Do you shake your slaues nodle?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And heer's a raskall lookt asway too, (sauing the pre, seace of maister Goldstone;) a filthy-slymy-lousie-nitticall broker, prickt vp in pawnes from the hat-band to the shoostring a necessary hooke to hang gentlemens suites ont it'h Aire, least they should grow musty with long lying? which his pawnes seldome are guilty off, a fellow of seuerall sents and Seeamea; French, Duch, Italian, English, and therefore his lice must needs be mungrells. why Bill mony?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am sorry to heere this among you, y'aue all deceiu'd me, truly I tooke you for other Spirits, you must pardon mee hence-forward, I haue a reputation to looke to, I must bee no more seene in your companies;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, nay, maister Golstone, you must not scape so yfaith, one word before you go sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray dispatch then, I would not for halfe my reuenewes yfaith now, that any gallants should passe by in the meane time, and finde me in your companies, nay as quicke as you can sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You did not take away maister Bowcers cloake tother morning, pawnd it to me and borrowed fiue pound vppon't;

sp.speaker: Gold
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Twas not you neither that finely cheated my little Nouice at maister Primeroes house, of a Diamond and Saphire, and swore they were counterfet, both glasse, meere glasse as you were a right gentleman;

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Slife, why were we strangers all this while? sfoot I perceicue wee are all naturall Brothers? a pox ons all are we found yfaith?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: A cheater?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A theese, a lecher, a bawd and a Broker?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: What meane they to bee so merry, Im'e afraid they laugh at vs and make fooles on's.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Push, leaue it to me— how now: who would you speake withall?

sp.speaker: Cunst.
sp.p: Speak withall? haue wee waited all this while, for a suspected theefe?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How? your'r scarce awake yet I thinke, looke well, does any appeare like a theefe in this company▪ away you slaues, you stand loytring, when you should looke to the common wealth? you catch knaues apace now, do you not? they may walke by your nose, you raskals?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sweete Maister Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You lackt spirit in your company, till I came among you▪ here bee fiue on's, lets but glew together, why now the world shall not come betweene vs.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: If we be true among our selues.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why true; we cannot lack to be rich; for we cannot lack riches, nor can our wenches want, nor we want wenches.

sp.speaker: Prl.
sp.p: Let me alone to furnish you with them.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And me.

lg.l: Theres one care past: and as for the Knights daughter,
Our chiefest businesse, and least thought vpon.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Thats true ifaith.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: How shall we agree for her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With as much ease as for the rest: to morrow brings the night, lets all appeare in the best shape we may; troth is, we haue need on't, and when amongst vs fiue she makes election, as one she shall choose.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: True, she cannot choose.

lg.l: That one so fortunate amongst vs fiue,
Shall beare himselfe more portly, liue regarded,
Keepe house, and be a countenance to the rest.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Admirall.

lg.l: For instance, put case your selfe after some robbery done
Were pursu'de hardly; why there were your shelter,
You know your Sanctuary: nay say you were taken,
His letter to the Iustice will strik't dead,
'Tis policie to receiue one for the head.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lets hug thee Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What haue I begot?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I must plot for you all, it likes me rarely.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Prethee what ist sir?

lg.l: 'Twould strike Fitsgraue pale,
And make the other Suiters appeare blanckes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: For our vnited misteries.

lg.l: What if we fiu: presented our full shapes
In a Strange-gallant, and conceited maske?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: In a maske, your thoughts and mine were twins.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: So the deuice were subtle nothing like it.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Some Poet must assist vs▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Poet? youle take the direct line to haue vs sta'gde? why what lacks Bowser, are you too well, too safe, an absolute scholler, easie to be wrought, no danger in the operation.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: But haue you so much interest▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: What in Bowser? why my least word commends him:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Then no man fitter.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: And there's Maister Frip too, can furnish furnish vs of masking suites 〈…〉 enow.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Vpon sufficient pawne I thinke I can sir▪

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Pawne? I owe, here take my chaine: pawnes among brothers? we shall thriue? but wee must still expect one roague in fiue, and thinke vs happy too.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Last man we spoke on, Maister Bowser.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Little maister Bowser, sweete maister Bowser welcome ifaith?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Are your fathers dead▪ gentlemen, y'are so merry.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: By my troth a good iest, did not I commend his wit to you gentlemen, harke sirra Rafe Bowser, co●●● Bowser ifaith? thers a kind of portion in towne, a girle of 15 hundred, whom we al powrefully affect, and determine to present our parts to her in a Maske.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: In a Maske!

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Right sir, now a little of thy braine for a deuice to present vs firme, which wee shall neuer bee able to do our selues thou knowst that; and with a kind of speech wherein thou mayst expresse what gallants are▪ brauely;

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Puh, how can I expresse em otherwise but brauely: now for a Mercury and al were fitted.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Could not a boy supply it?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Why none better.

lg.l: I haue a boy shal put down al the Mercuries ith towne,
A will play a Mercury naturally, at his fingers end ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Why then wee are suted; for torch-bearers and sheeld-boies, these are alwaies the writers properties; y'are not troubled with them.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Come my little Bowser; do't finely now, to the life.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I warrant you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Hist; giue me a little touch aboue the rest and you can possible, for I meane to present this chaine of pearle to her.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Now I know that let me alone to fit you.

div.head: ACT. 5.

sp.speaker: I. Cur.
sp.p: Come forth you wary priuate— why spring strumpet haue we found your closse. haunts, your priuate watchtowers, and your subtill meanes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt▪
sp.p: You can steale secretly hether, you misticall queane you, at twylight, twitterlights you haue a priviledge from your hat forsooth, to walke without a man, and no suspition, But we poore gentlewomen that goe in Tires Haue no such liberty we cannot do thus▪ Custome grants that to you thats shame in vs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Haue you donne yet?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: You broke the backe of one husband already & now th' others dead with griefe at sea, with your secret expences, close stelths cunning filches, and continued banquets in corners; then forsooth you must haue your milke-baths to white you, your rose-leaues to sweeten you, your beane-floure bags, to sleeke you, and make you soft, smoothe, & delicate, for lasciuious entertainement.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, and you thinke all this while you dance like a theese in a mist y'are safe, no body can finde you; pray were not you a Pillmongers daughter at first, that runne away with a new Courtiar for the loue of Gentlewomens clothes, and bought the fashion at a deere rate, with the losse of your name & credit, why what are all of you, but rusticall insides, and citty flesh, the bloud of yeomen, and the bum of gentlewomen—

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: What shall wee suffer a changeable forepart to out-tongue vs, take that.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Murder, murder—

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p:
How now? why Ladies, a retreate, come, you haue showne your spirits sufficiently, yare all land captaines, and so they shall finde that come in your quarters, but haue you the law free now to fight and scrath among your selues and let your
Gallants run away with vs.

sp.speaker: 1. Curti.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: 2. Cur.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: Sweete maister Bowser.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Why then I perceiue you know nothing: why they are in the way of marriage:
A knights daughter here in towne makes her election among em this night.

sp.speaker: 1. Cur.
sp.p: This night?

sp.speaker: Fitsg.
sp.p: This very night, and they all present themselues in a maske before her, know you not this?

sp.speaker: 2. Curt.
sp.p: O traitor Maister Goldstone.

sp.speaker: 3. Cur.
sp.p: Periurde Maister Taylbee:

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Without soule?

sp.speaker: 1. Curt.
sp.p: She will chase him.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: You haue more cause to ioyne, and play the grounds of friendship mongst your selues, then rashly run diuisional could tell you a meanes to pleasure you:
Good maister Bowser.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: But that y'are women and are hardly secret.
We vow it seriously?

lg.l: You should be all there in presence▪
See all, heare all, and yet not they percieue you.

sp.p: So that—

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Sweete maister Bowser,— I

lg.l: I can stand you in stead,
For I frame the deuice,—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: If euer—

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Will you do't— harke you—
Content.
And ile make one.

lg.l: And I another,
Weele marre the match,
When that good newes came of my husbands death,
Goldstone promist me marriage.
and Sweare to me.

sp.p: Ile bring his oths in question▪
So will I:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Agree among your selues, for shame.
Are we resolude?
In this who would not faine,
Friends all for my part,
Heer's my lip for thine▪
Round let it go,
All wrath thus quencht,
And I conclude it so.

sp.speaker: Prip.
sp.p: How all euents strike euen with my wishes, Their owne inuention damnes them,— now Gentlemen? stands your assistance firme?

lg.l: Why 'tis our owne case,
Ime sorry you should doubt.

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.p: Weele furnish you?
Are these our Gallants?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Are our Gallants these?

sp.speaker: Paynt.
sp.p: Heere be fiue shields sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Finisht already, thats well? Ile see thy maister shortly▪

sp.speaker: Pain
sp.p: Ime satisfied.

sp.speaker: Pia.
sp.p: Prithee lets see maister Fitsgraue,

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I haue blaz'd them,

lg.l: Whats this;
Fooh, you should be a gallant too, for you'r no vniuersity Scholler?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Looke this is Pursuit:, the deuice, a purse wide open, and the mouth downeward. The wood, Alienis ecce crumenis.
Whats that?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: One that liues out of other mens pockets,

sp.speaker: Pya
sp.p: Thats right?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Heer's Goldstones three siluer dice,
They run hye, two sincks and a quater?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: They'r hye men fit for his purposes— The word, Fratremque Patremque

sp.speaker: 2. Gal.
sp.p: Nay he will cheat his owne brother, nay his owne father ifaith?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: So much the word imports— Maister Primero,
Pox what saies he now?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The deuice, an vnuallued pearle, hid in a caue. The word, Occulos vendit honores,
What's that▪

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: One that sells maidenheads by whole-sale;
Excellently proper?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Maister Frip?
That pythagoricall raskall, in a gentlemans suite to day, in a knights to morrow:

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The deuise for him; a Cuckow sitting on a tree? The word, En auis ex auibus; one bird made of many; for you know as the Sparrow hatches the Cuckow, so the Gentleman fethers the Broker?
Let me admire thee, maister Fitsgraue?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: They will scorne gentlemen: and to assist them the better, Pursnets boy that little pretious pick-pocket, has a compendious speech in lattin, and like a Mercury presents their their dispositions more liberally:
Neuer were poore gallants so abused?

sp.speaker: Fits.

lg.l: Hang 'em, their counterfets, no honest spirit will pitty 'em▪
This is my Crowne,
So good men smile I dread no raskalls frowne.

sp.p: Away, bestow your selues secretly, ore'head, this is the place appointed for the rehearsall, to practise their behauiours.
We are vanisht.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Maister Bowcer,

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Welsaid yfaith, off with your cloakes gallants, let's fall roundly to our busines:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Is the boy perfect?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: That's my credit sir, I warrant you?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: If our little Mercury should bee out, wee should scarce be knowne what we are▪

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I haue tooke a course for that, feare it not sir; looke you first heere be your Sheilds:

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I Where be our Sheilds?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: which is mine?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Which is mine maister Bowcer? this?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I pray be contained a little gentlemen, they'l come all time ynough to you, I warrant:

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: This Frip is growne so violent;

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Yours to begin withall sir?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: welsaid maister Bowcer, first the Deuice, a fair purse wide open, the mouth downeward, the word Alienis ecce crumenis?

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Whats that prithee?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Your bounty powres it selfe forth to all men.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: And so it does ifaith? that's all my fault, bountifull?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Maister Goldstone heers yours sir, 3. siluer Dice, the word, Fratremque Patremque?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: And whats that?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Fortune of my side?

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: Welsaid little Bowcer yfaith?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: What say you to me sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: For the deuice A Candle in a corner; the word, Consumptio, Victus:

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: The meaning of that sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: My light is yet in darknes, till I inioy her, right sir?

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: Now mine sir?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The Deuice an vnuallued pearle hid in a Caue.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Ah ha sirs?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The word, Occultes vendit honores;

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Very-good I warrant,

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: A black mans a pearle in a faire Ladyes eye,

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I said twas some such thing;

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: My turne must needs come now; am I fitted Maister Bowcer?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Trust to me, your deuice here is a Cuckow sitting on a tree,

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The Welsh Lidger, good.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The word, En Anis ex Auibus.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I marry sir.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Why do you know what 'tis sir.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No by my troth not yet sir▪

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Oh, I keepe one tune, I recant not.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I me like the Cuckow in that indeed, where I loue I hold.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Did I not promise you I would fit you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: They re all very well done ifaith, and very Schollerlike, tho I say't before thy face little Bowcer, but I would not haue thee proud ont now: come if this be performde well.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Who the Boy, he has performd deeper matters then this.

sp.speaker: Pyam.
sp.p: I a pox on him, I thinke was in my pocket now, and truth were knowne.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: I caught him once in mine.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Suppose the shields are presented, then you begin boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I representing Mercury, am a Pick-pocket, and haue his part at my fingers ends, Page I am to that great and secret theefe, magno illo et Secreto Latroni.

sp.speaker: Bungl.
sp.p: There you make your honor sir▪

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: At Latroni.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: You haue it sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Latroni, thats mine.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: He confesses the Theefe's his.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Remember boy, you point Latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To you Maister, proceede▪

sp.speaker: Ftis.
sp.p: These foure are his companions, the one a notable cheater, that will coosen his owne father.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Maister Goldstone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let mee alone maister Boucer, I can take mine owne turne.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: Why.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: The second an notorious letcher maintained by harlots cuius virtus consumptio corpus.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Thats I maister Bowcer.

sp.speaker: Bou.
sp.p: There you remember your honor sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ille leno pretiosissimus, Virgineos ob lucrum vendens honores.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: It sounds very well yfaith.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Postremus ille, quamuis apparatus splendidus, is no otherwise but a Broker, these fethers are not his owne, sed anis ex Auibus; all which to bee nothing but truth, will appeare by the euent.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Ifaith here's all now Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Short and pithy.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A good boy yfaith and a pregnant.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: I dare put trust in the Boy sir; forget not sirrah at any▪ hand to point that same Latroni to me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I warrant you maister.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen the time beckons vs away.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I, furnish Gentlemen, furnish.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Harke one word maister Boucer, what's the same Latroni, I haue a good minde to that word ifaith.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Latroni? why Sheerse of the Sheere.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Ifaith? and I haue shriuen some sheeres in my daies.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Now gentlemen are you satsfied and pleasd?
Neuer more amply▪

lg.l: Amongst vs now falls that desired lot,
For we shall blast fiue riualls with one plot.

div.stage: Enter the Virgin betweene two antient gentlemen.

lg.l: Graue gentlemen, in whose approued bosomes,
My deceast father did repose much faith
Your deerely welcome: pray sit, command musick,
See nothing want to beautifie this night,
That holds my election in her peacefull armes,
Feasts, Musick, Hymnes, those sweete celestiall swarmes.

sp.p: May you be blest in this election.
That content, may meete perfection.

lg.head: Himne.
lg.l: Sound Lute. Bandora, Gitterne,
Uioll, Virginalls and Sithron!
Uoices spring and lift alowde,
Her name that makes the Musick proud:
this night perfection,
makes her election:
Follow, follow follow, follow round,
Looke you to that, nay you to that, nay you to that:
Anon, you will be found, anon you will bee found, anon you will bee found.

div.stage: Enter the maske, thus ordered. A torchbearer, a sheeld-boy, then a masker, so throughout, then the sheeld-boyes fall at one end, the torchbearers at the other; the maskers ith middle, the torch-bearers are the fiue gentlemen: the sheeld-boies the whores in boies apparrel: the maskers the fiue Gallants, they bow to her she rises and shewes the like, they dance but first deliuer the sheeldes vp; shee reades.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Alienis ecce crumenis.

sp.speaker: Pursn.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Fratremque, Patremque.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Consumptio victus.

sp.speaker: Taylbe
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath
sp.p: Occultos vendit honores.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: A Cuckow: en anis ex auibus.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Bowes to her.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Are you all as the speech and shields display you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Wee shall prooue so.

div.stage: They going to dance, each vnhaspes his weapon from his side, and giues em to the torch-bearers. Katherine seemes distrustfull, but then Fisgraue whispers to her and falls backe. At the end of which all making an honor, Frip presents her with that chaine of Pearle.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: The very chaine of Pearle was filcht from me.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Hold stop the boy there.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.p: Will none lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Alas Ime but a broker, 'twas pawnd to me in my shop.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Ha, Fitsgraue?

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.p: Peamont and the rest.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Where's Boucer?

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Heere.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Wee are all betraide.

sp.speaker: Fits
sp.p: Betrayde▪ y' are new forth to betrayde, you haue not so much worth: nay struggle not with the net, you are caught for this world.

sp.speaker: 1 Curt.
sp.p: Would we were out.

sp.speaker: Fits.

lg.l: 'Twas I fram'd your deuise: do you see 'twas I;
The whole assembly has tooke notice of it,
That you are a gallant cheator,
So much the pawning of my cloake containes▪

sp.p: You a base theefe, thinke of Coome-parke and tell me that your a hired Smokster, heres her letter. In which we are certified that you are a Bawde.
The broker has confest it.
So has the boy.

sp.speaker: Taylb.
sp.p: That boy wilbe hangd, he stole the chaine at first and has thus long maintainde his maisters Gallantry.

lg.l: All which we here present like captiue slaues,
Waiting that doome which their presumption craues.
How easily may our suspectlesse sexe,
With faire appeering shadowes be deluded:
Deare sir, you haue the worke so well begun,
That tooke from you small glory would be wonne.
Since tis your pleasure to refer to me,
The doome of these; I haue prouided so:
They shall not altogither loose their cost;
See I haue brought wiues for em.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Heart, the strumpets— out, out▪

lg.l: Hauing assum'd out of their impudence,
The shape of sheeld-boyes.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: To heapefull confusion.

lg.l: Rather confine vs to strikt chastity▪
A meere impossible taske then to wed these:
Whom we loth worse then the foul'st desease.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: O grant em their requestes.

lg.l: The doome is past,
So since your aime was mariage:
Either imbrace it in these Curtizans,
Or haue your base acts, and fellonius liues
Proclaimd to the indignation of the law,
Which will prouide a publike punishment:
As for the boy, and that infectious Bawde,
We put forth those to whipping.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Whipping? you finde not that in the statute to whip sattin.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p:
Since all our shifts are discouered, as farre as I can see tis
our best course to marry em: weele make them get our liuings.

sp.speaker: Purs
sp.p: He saies true.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You see how we are threatened, by my troth wenches be rul'd by me, lets many em and it bee but to plauge em; for when we haue husbands we are vnder couert-baron, and may lie with whom wee list; I haue tri'd that in my tother husbands daies.

sp.speaker: All Curt.
sp.p: A match.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: Ile be no more deferd▪ come, when do you ioyne:

sp.speaker: Gol.
sp.p: These forc'd marriages do neuer come to good.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: How can they, when the come to such as you?

lg.l: The often prooue the ruine of great houses,
Nor Virgin do I in this seeke to entice:
All glory to my selfe; these Gentlemen,
To whome I am bound to loue for kinde assistance,
Had great affinity in the plot with me.
To them I giue my thankes: my selfe to thee,
Thrice worthy Fitsgraue.

sp.speaker: Fits.
sp.p: I ha●●ll my wishes.

lg.l: And I presume ther's none but those can frowne,
Whose enuis like the rushes we tread downe.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
